headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Kohl's Q1 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Certain statements made on this call, including projected financial results, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Secu
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Kohl's Q1 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Certain statements made on this call, including projected financial results, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Kohl's intends forward-looking terminology, such as believes, expects, may, will, should, anticipates, plans or similar expressions to identify forward-looking statements.
Such statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties which could cause Kohl's actual results to differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements.
Such risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to, those that are described in Item 1A in Kohl's most recent annual report on Form 10-K and as may be supplemented from time to time in Kohl's other filings with the SEC, all of which are expressly incorporated herein by reference.
Also, please note that replays of this recording will not be updated. So if you're listening after May 12, 2016, it is possible that the information discussed is no longer current. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Wes McDonald, Chief Financial Officer of Kohl's Department Stores. Please go ahead.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. With me today is Kevin Mansell, our Chairman, CEO and President. I'l start today's call by walking through our operational results. Kevin will then provide more details on our Greatness Agenda initiatives and then we'll take some
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. With me today is Kevin Mansell, our Chairman, CEO and President. I'l start today's call by walking through our operational results. Kevin will then provide more details on our Greatness Agenda initiatives and then we'll take some of your questions.
Comp sales decrease 3.9% for the quarter. Transactions per store were down 4.8% for the quarter. Average transaction value increased 90 basis points comprised of 190 basis point increase in units per transaction and 100 basis points decrease in average unit retail.
From a line of business perspective, men's and women's were the strongest categories and home was the weakest. On a regional basis, the Northeast, Mid-Atlantic, Southeast and Midwest were the strongest. The West and South Central were the most difficult regions.
Gross margin decrease approximately 140 basis points for the quarter, about 10 basis points better than we guided to last quarter. Most of the margin decrease was due to Clarence markdowns, taken the clear excess merchandise. 
Our SG&A expenses decreased $8 million to $1 billion for the quarter. We effectively manage discretionary spending but we're you're not able to leverage expenses on a sales decrease. As a percentage of sales, SG&A deleveraged 75 basis points.
Store payroll dollars were slightly higher than last year as we pulled back on staffing to align with sales but did not leverage. Marketing deleveraged on higher spending associated with our Academy Awards sponsorship and higher digital spending. IT expenses also deleveraged.
Partially offsetting these increases were higher credit income and lower corporate expenses. Our credit share of sales was 58.8%, up 81 basis points from last year. Logistics expenses were also less than last year.
Depreciation expense was $234 million. The $7 million increase over last year is primarily due to higher IT amortization. Interest expense decreased $5 million to $79 million for the quarter. The decrease is due to favorable interest rates achieved during our $1.1 billion debt refinancing last summer.
Our income tax rate was 37.6%. The tax rate increased approximately 230 basis points as last year's first quarter included some favorable tax -- state tax audit settlements that we didn't have this year.
Net income on a reported GAAP basis for the quarter was $17 million and diluted earnings per share were $0.09. For the quarter, we reported $64 million of expenses related to the store closures and corporate restructuring that we announced earlier this year. The charge includes $53 million of impairment charges on the 18 stores, which we closed later this year. The remaining $11 million is primarily termination benefits for employees impacted by the closures and restructuring.
We expect to incur an additional $105 million to $110 million next quarter, which is slightly higher than our original estimates as we have more store associates than expected due to termination packages over relocation to another stories. 
Substantially, all of next quarter's charge will be to record lease related liabilities for stores we are closing prior to lease termination.
Excluding the store closures and restructuring charges, net income was $58 million and diluted earnings per share was $0.31 per share. We opened 3 new stores during the quarter, including our first 2 smaller 35,000 square foot format pilot stores. We currently operate 1,167 stores.
Gross square footage is 100.6 million square feet and selling square footage is 83.9 million square feet. We also open 2 Off-Aisle stores in the Milwaukee market. We ended quarter with $423 million of cash and cash equivalents, a decrease of $772 million from last year. 
Inventory dollars per store were 2% lower than the first quarter of 2015 consistent with our guidance of down low single-digits despite the challenging sales environment.
Units per store were essentially flat as increases in national brand were more than offset by decreases in private and exclusive brands. AP as a percent of inventory decreased 650 basis points to 32.9%. All of the decrease is due to lower receipts.
We also received some benefit in Q1 and Q2 of last year due to earlier arrive in receipts related to conservative planning after the port disruption in fall 2014 and spring 2015. Receipt flow year-over-year should be normalized by the third quarter of 2016. 
Capital expenditures were $177 million for the quarter, consistent with the first quarter of last year. Weighted average diluted shares were 184 million for the quarter. During the quarter, we repurchased 2.8 million shares of our stock. We ended the quarter with 185 million shares of stock outstanding.
On Wednesday, our board declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.50 per share. The dividend is payable on June 22 to shareholders of record on June 8. 
I'll note it over to Kevin, who will provide additional insights on our results.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Wes. The first quarter was well below our expectations in the sales line as a very strong start to the quarter in February was overcome by softer-than-expected pre-Easter business and then a further deterioration in April versus our plans. Our sea
componenttext:
Thanks, Wes. The first quarter was well below our expectations in the sales line as a very strong start to the quarter in February was overcome by softer-than-expected pre-Easter business and then a further deterioration in April versus our plans. Our seasonal business has followed similar trajectory as a total company sales trend. 
A little more color on our sales. Men's and women's were better than the company with strength in active across both of those categories. Basic and dress clothing were relatively strong in man's but juniors and intimate were better in women's.
Kids, Accessories and shoes were similar to the company with relative strength in boys and girls, beauty and fine jewelry as well as kid's shoes. Home was below the company with bedding, luggage and seasonal being outperformance with the balance being more difficult.
We did do a good job of managing our inventory, gross margin and expenses during the quarter. Our gross margin rate dropped 140 basis points versus our projection of 150 basis points of a drop due to better-than-planned promotional markdowns. Our inventory per store is now down 2%, in line with our expectations at the beginning of the year.
We continue to expect to make progress on inventory throughout this year, and we're targeting end the second quarter levels of down mid-single digits on a per-store basis. 
On the SG&A line, every area of the company was able to pull back on their planned expenses to allow us to spend slightly less than last year in dollars versus our expectations originally of a 3% to 4% planned increase.
The team has shown as you would B2B able to pull back on expenses in a difficult sales environment. Now I'd like to take a few minutes to update you on some of the initiatives within the Greatness Agenda.
Now focus on product initiatives, our national brands in the first quarter we launched Stride Rite and kid's shoes and relaunched New Balance in the active area. The launch of Stride Rite helped kid's shoes to outperform and New Balance achieved a 19% comp in the quarter.
Our national brands in total were slightly positive on a comp basis but active and wellness leading the way with a mid-single-digit comp. Nike continues to be very strong, achieving a midteens comp in the quarter.
National brand penetration increased approximately 200 basis points in the quarter. We relaunched SONOMA in the first quarter and have been happy with the results in both men's and women's as they've seen improvements versus their priority trend. 
During the quarter, we also launched read from regret and handbags as improving our Accessories assortment has been a goal for us and it's off to a very good start. 
Our localization efforts are proving out and 2016 will be the year that all of our planning efforts for unique assortments by store will come to life in 90% of our store fleet. As we enter the second quarter, approximately 70% of the assortment is now localized. We saw modest lift in quarter 1 but would expect the effect of this to improve as we gain more experience and enter key transitional periods like second and third quarter where localized assortments should make a bigger impact.
In our focus around omnichannel initiatives, we continue to see strong results in digital demand with online generated demand achieving a midteens increase, as expected. We continue to invest in technology and training in our stores to allow us to Ship from Store and provide Buy Online, Pick Up In Store capabilities, providing faster shipping times and more convenience for our customer.
In the first quarter, Ship from Store was 15% of our online demand and Buy Online, Pick Up In Store was 3%. We believe we have a big opportunity there and we'll continue to test marketing that option throughout the year to make a top of mind in our customers for holiday.
Our Kohl's app was used by more than 12 million customers and growing. During the quarter, we added capability to use Apple Pay with our Kohl's Charge Card and our Yes2You Rewards loyalty program, becoming the first retailer to integrate its private-label charge card and loyalty program within Apple Pay. 
On a store update front, we opened 2 small format stores during the quarter and we have a lot of learnings already that we will incorporate into our fall plan openings. A big learning was to be flexible and our offerings as each trade area is unique due to the relatively small size of the trade areas and our smaller store size as well.
Localization we believe will be critical for our success in this initiative. We also opened 2 Off-Aisle stores in the Milwaukee area, 1 in the off-price center in 1 in a strip center. We're pleased to the initial results, and we'll monitor the effects on cannibalization, which we would expect be very small. And in late May we'll open 12 Fila stores to gauge the possibilities in the outlet space.
Moving on to expenses. I mentioned in the year-end call that we're beginning an effort to reduce our leverage point on expenses from a 2% comparable sales increase to a 1.5% comparable sales increase. Despite the fact we're experiencing significant wage pressure in our stores and intend to continue to invest in our omnichannel initiatives, we feel more confident that we'll be able to achieve that goal.
I think, you can see that given our ability to manage expenses in the first quarter. We expect to find additional savings throughout the year that will allow us to achieve our expense goals. 
In conclusion, it was definitely a difficult start to 2016. It's hard to gauge how much of the sales shortfall is related to macroeconomic factors and how much is related to company-specific factors. We definitely focus on improving our sales but especially our traffic to brick-and-mortar stores. We're relooking in all of our marketing vehicle to see where we can drive more business to the stores as well as ensuring our value message is particularly strong. Definitely not satisfied with the results so far and we'll take action every top of mind with the families that we serve. 
And with that, we'll be happy to take your questions.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, pricing is definitely an element of our review in the comments that I made around marketing, Matt. Our private brands underperformed our national brands, the national brand penetration went up almost 200 basis points again. The trend line on some of
componenttext: Well, pricing is definitely an element of our review in the comments that I made around marketing, Matt. Our private brands underperformed our national brands, the national brand penetration went up almost 200 basis points again. The trend line on some of the private brands, particularly SONOMA, definitely improved when we relaunched it. Pricing is always a big factor. I don't know that we would call out any particularly noticeable promotional effort by other retailers that I see having a major effect on how we're going to go to market. But when we think about improving the trend line from the disappointment in the first quarter to improve number in second quarter, we're definitely looking at pricing, we're definitely looking at our marketing vehicles and the level of marketing we have to spend to get traction, particularly in our traffic and brick-and-mortar stores.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's less about price in the private brands and more about product. So we have some private brands that are doing very well like so in our juniors area. The juniors continued its strength period over from last fall, where our other private br
componenttext: Yes, I think it's less about price in the private brands and more about product. So we have some private brands that are doing very well like so in our juniors area. The juniors continued its strength period over from last fall, where our other private brands are a little tougher. So I think it's just a combination of both.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on a follow-up on the capital allocation, Wes, what's the minimum cash balance your comfortable with on the balance sheet? And then the best way to evaluate share repurchase versus [indiscernible] I mean almost the 5% dividend yield going
componenttext: Got it. And then on a follow-up on the capital allocation, Wes, what's the minimum cash balance your comfortable with on the balance sheet? And then the best way to evaluate share repurchase versus [indiscernible] I mean almost the 5% dividend yield going forward?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the #1 priority for cash is to fund our growth so we'll continue to invest in the digital technologies and to drive that business. So our CapEx for this year is $825 million that remains the case. We want to -- we're committed to growing the
componenttext: Well, I think the #1 priority for cash is to fund our growth so we'll continue to invest in the digital technologies and to drive that business. So our CapEx for this year is $825 million that remains the case. We want to -- we're committed to growing the dividend about 10% and the remainder of that will be left over for share repurchase. So we're still targeting $600 million for the year. We were light to that this quarter. We'll all take a look at our grid and put in a new grid and target the same $150 million for this quarter. For the end of the year, where we ended last year, I think it was around $700 million. That's about where we want to be. So I don't see any particular reason to go lower or higher than that. So given our projections, we would still be able to buy back $600 million this year.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question from Mark Altschwager from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question from Mark Altschwager from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the inventory. You did a nice job hitting our plans, however, given the much weaker-than-expected sales environment, it's still running and ahead of comp. So I guess how much facility do you have the deck a further step down in the squeezes for th
componenttext: Just on the inventory. You did a nice job hitting our plans, however, given the much weaker-than-expected sales environment, it's still running and ahead of comp. So I guess how much facility do you have the deck a further step down in the squeezes for the back half of the year and then how should we do about that inventory progression?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: The back half of the year is consistent with the second quarter we would expect our inventories to be down mid-single digits on upper store base is so further reduction from where we are today and that's really going to be a function of receipts, which we
componenttext: The back half of the year is consistent with the second quarter we would expect our inventories to be down mid-single digits on upper store base is so further reduction from where we are today and that's really going to be a function of receipts, which we've already planned and worked with our vendors on. So I suspect, absent any kind the change further downward, we should be able to hit those end of quarter goals.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the other thing I would add, Mark, it there wasn't a lot to get very excited about it in that first quarter performance but 1 thing that I did the team did well and, I think, we're going to be well positioned. Regardless of where the business goes
componenttext: I mean, the other thing I would add, Mark, it there wasn't a lot to get very excited about it in that first quarter performance but 1 thing that I did the team did well and, I think, we're going to be well positioned. Regardless of where the business goes the remaining of the year is receipt flow and inventory, and we are down to last year, you're going to be down further than that as we go into third quarter and the demonstrated, I think, the ability to be agile and bring on receipts is necessary. So that I think is a little bit of a bright spot.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a quick follow-up on SG&A. You addressed the longer-term leverage point. But how sustainable is this down 1% run rate and should the negative comp environment continue over the next couple of quarters, just talk about the puts and takes there?
componenttext: And then a quick follow-up on SG&A. You addressed the longer-term leverage point. But how sustainable is this down 1% run rate and should the negative comp environment continue over the next couple of quarters, just talk about the puts and takes there?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our SG&A guidance like you saw was to leverage at 1.5 comp. I expect us I think that translated into like 1% to 2% dollars for the year if I recall correctly. We're going to have to be lower than the 1%, I think, we show that we could do that this
componenttext: I think our SG&A guidance like you saw was to leverage at 1.5 comp. I expect us I think that translated into like 1% to 2% dollars for the year if I recall correctly. We're going to have to be lower than the 1%, I think, we show that we could do that this quarter. It wasn't all just related to any one thing, as Kevin mentioned, every area the company has participated in bringing down their expenses. We have a lot of things underway to further reduce expenses that allowed us to get to that point and that will continue to see that come to fruition throughout the year. But my expectation is for estimate for the year would be somewhere between flat to up 1. So I think we can take it down a level from where we are today.

componenttextpreview: Which Wes said was essentially flat and a modest increase on a comp basis and also EPS. The first quarter as you know, is a really small percentage of the total year both on a sales basis but in particular on an EPS basis. I think for the fourth quarter,
componenttext: Which Wes said was essentially flat and a modest increase on a comp basis and also EPS. The first quarter as you know, is a really small percentage of the total year both on a sales basis but in particular on an EPS basis. I think for the fourth quarter, our expected earnings per share was probably around $0.40, which would be less than 10% of the annual expectation that we gave. So we really just barely into the year. For us to look forward and make some forecast change based on a really sharp percentage of the year and a very small percentage of the total, I think, just be wrong. We are obviously making plans far being more defensive around things, as Wes said, like inventory are like expenses to be prepared to bring down. But we still feel good that the sales trend will improve in the second quarter, and we definitely feel like it will improve further as we go into the back half.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: And what are the reasons behind the good feelings around comp improving?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on a comp basis, we've kind of articulated them in the beginning of the year guidance. One of the big things that you know that hurt us in the third and fourth quarter last year was a build up in inventory that really took away all of our flexibil
componenttext: I think on a comp basis, we've kind of articulated them in the beginning of the year guidance. One of the big things that you know that hurt us in the third and fourth quarter last year was a build up in inventory that really took away all of our flexibility to adjust receipts into categories that were outperforming other areas. And so 1 of the big things, I think, Wes and I both really feel about is our inventory position put us in a space where we can see the businesses that are performing. We have a business that are outperforming other businesses in spite of lower traffic levels, particularly lower traffic in March and April. We have categories that are actually doing well. With talked about some of those and so we want to be in a where we can feed those. I don't know if you want to add anything, Wes?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: You're sitting our expectation for the rest of the year will be flat to 1 for the remaining quarters. So That when you do the math, you guys are smart, that probably puts it toward the lower end of the comp range may be a little bit below, which is why we think that we need to take our expenses down to achieve the earnings guidance that we gave. As Kevin mentioned, it's less than 10% of expectations for the earnings for the year so we feel like there's a lot of room in front of it that we can do different things to try to make that earnings.

componenttext: No, I think that would be liquid to put the screws of the inventor a little bit more. We have to invest for the long term. Much like maces reported yesterday, we had a very strong February with the first positive comp we run since 2011 then we saw a pretty dramatic drop off the same timing that they mentioned. So we'll have to save that drop-off is the macro induced thing or if it's company-specific. We'll know a lot more as more companies report later this week. But it will get warm. We have short to sell, and we're in a good inventory position. So I think at some point, people in need of those quotes I will combine them.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean the area, I think Wes and I agree the area probably getting more scrutiny I know necessarily impacts this year's actual capital expenditure but looking out this year through year 2 and year 3 forward, are probably CapEx around technology, Wes, is d
componenttext: I mean the area, I think Wes and I agree the area probably getting more scrutiny I know necessarily impacts this year's actual capital expenditure but looking out this year through year 2 and year 3 forward, are probably CapEx around technology, Wes, is definitely getting more scrutiny from us as we look at whether or not the investments we're making are giving us the return that we expected to get from them. And the second thing is definitely capital that's dedicated towards fulfillment of our online generated demand regardless of whether that capital is in our stores or that capital is in technology or that capital is in a fulfillment center either existing or future to come. Those 2 are probably reason to the top in terms of areas we're looking at.

componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to discuss a little bit further the composition and cadence of the comp. I believe in the fourth quarter and generally through 2015, transactions per store were roughly flattish. And so given the down 4.8 this quarter and the solid start in Fe
componenttext: Just wanted to discuss a little bit further the composition and cadence of the comp. I believe in the fourth quarter and generally through 2015, transactions per store were roughly flattish. And so given the down 4.8 this quarter and the solid start in February, is it fair to assume that you are exiting the quarter those last 4 or 5 weeks kind of down 8%, 9%, 10%? And if so, can you give a little bit more detail on the those -- on the seasonal goods performance specifically, Wes, I know you mentioned whether that, that shorts weren't selling. So maybe you can give us a little bit more of a handle on what kind of bounce back you might expect if the weather does warm up? And then lastly, on the outcome, AUR was down 100 basis points. Wes, do you expect that to be just unique to the first quarter given the aggressive promotions?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, those were a lot of questions for a 1 but I'll try to answer most of for them. They were the mostly for the clearance I would expect that to be onetime phenomenon in the first quarter. Your math on the comp for the balance of the quarter wasn't corre
componenttext: Yes, those were a lot of questions for a 1 but I'll try to answer most of for them. They were the mostly for the clearance I would expect that to be onetime phenomenon in the first quarter. Your math on the comp for the balance of the quarter wasn't correct but you are directionally correct. If you're positive in the first month, you've got to be negative in the last 2. From a seasonal perspective, our spring seasonal goods were good in February, pour in March and April kind of consistent with the palms. They were worse than the company by a couple of hundred basis points. It's a fairly significant part of the business but as we mentioned, home was the worst category, which wouldn't have much seasonality to it. We've got to improve traffic, that's somewhat of the marketing issue that we've got to try to resolve. It also relates to product once we get them into story, our conversion rates are actually improved we just have to get them into the store.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, just to be clear on 1 thing, as we look what drivers of comp, whether they are periods of positive comp we have for periods of negative comp like the first quarter, we try to prioritize in our minds that what the drivers are so we can attack those.
componenttext: Paul, just to be clear on 1 thing, as we look what drivers of comp, whether they are periods of positive comp we have for periods of negative comp like the first quarter, we try to prioritize in our minds that what the drivers are so we can attack those. Things like seasonal category performance, which often weather drives that, we don't think is that a buildup of the priority list in terms of things that were a driver of negative comp in the first quarter. Our seasonal categories underperformed for sure but they didn't significantly underperformed. So I do think Wes is either put them at the very top. We put things on the top, I think, we mentioned there seems to be some more macro issues given performances of both ourselves and competition. There seems to be some change in consumer behavior in terms of traffic coming into our stores, maybe because of that. We definitely have opportunity in our marketing area to improve our effectiveness. As we've moved in our media mix to a more traditional hold mix to a much more future state. We're finding things that have haven't worked as well that are probably that have of course corrected in the near term to get a better result. And then eventually as you get down to snow categories and you look at it and say yes, the seasonal categories, which is a very significant percent of our total business, underperformed. And if they performed as normal, we would have been a lot better. But I don't put it at the top.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful color. Lastly, for me. You stated that the comp guidance remains flat to 1 for the balance of the year. You modestly adjusted SG&A dollar growth. I think to now kind of more flat to up 1 for the balance of the year. Just on the gross m
componenttext: That's very helpful color. Lastly, for me. You stated that the comp guidance remains flat to 1 for the balance of the year. You modestly adjusted SG&A dollar growth. I think to now kind of more flat to up 1 for the balance of the year. Just on the gross margins, Wes, flat to  up 20, is that still attainable in your view? And if so, should we may be push a little bit more towards in the third and fourth quarter as opposed to 2Q just given the channel still seeing some traffic weakness or just help us out of the gross margins.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean before Wes mentions anything himself, I would just tell you, Paul, just to be clear. We're not updating anything. We're not updating ourselves. We're not updating our margin. We're not updating our SG&A and we're definitely not updating our earning
componenttext: I mean before Wes mentions anything himself, I would just tell you, Paul, just to be clear. We're not updating anything. We're not updating ourselves. We're not updating our margin. We're not updating our SG&A and we're definitely not updating our earnings. The first quarter is a small percentage of the year and there is not enough information we see to put us in position where we feel that we could knowledgeably tell you some type of update. We're just sort of targeting you to areas in which we're going to put more effort. And naturally, if you have a disappointment at the beginning of the year in sales, 1 area that's bubble up and we've got to put a lot more effort around is expense control and bringing down our ability to bring down expenses. Another area naturally is inventory. And ensuring that we not only can meet the lower levels of inventory we had planned going into the second and third quarter, but actually give ourselves ability to even bring it down further. So this -- I realize to some extent maybe it's new ones but, I think, it's an important distinction so we are trying to be a transparent and these are the things that we are doing in response to what we are seeing but there is no update to anything.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just as you do look back to this quarter, could you brief us in anything you might have gone differently if that was possible? And then does this tweak in terms of how you think about the broader Greatness Agenda just as you think about your strategic pla
componenttext: Just as you do look back to this quarter, could you brief us in anything you might have gone differently if that was possible? And then does this tweak in terms of how you think about the broader Greatness Agenda just as you think about your strategic plans? Also, on the traffic situation and regarding the softer pre-Easter and then April, what did you have any sense of it if it was a different -- if it was a specific demographic? Was there is something going on with the younger generation versus older in terms of thinking about where you are more sensitive and losing traffic?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can probably take a wack and I'll cover the first part and then Wes can talk about the traffic drivers. And essentially asking what you were asking is are there different actions you would have made had you known what was coming in terms of traffic into
componenttext: I can probably take a wack and I'll cover the first part and then Wes can talk about the traffic drivers. And essentially asking what you were asking is are there different actions you would have made had you known what was coming in terms of traffic into your stores. And I kind of view that in the short term and the long-term. On the long-term, right now, we actually feel pretty confident that the things we're working on are the right things and they remain the right things. Clearly, speed to get to here we want to be and our plan all those actions needs to be accelerated. We've got to get there faster, there is no question about that. Emphasis might change. So we typically midyear kind the review our long-term plan and our moves underneath the Greatness Agenda, and we might emphasize more 1 move versus another based on what we're seeing. But fundamentally, we still feel very confident about the plan that the plan is the right plan and our actions are the right actions. In the short term, I think, Wes and I both say, I think, we wish that some of our event handles and efforts were better. Had we known there's going to be some macro traffic issue and in particular I would say in April and had we known that some of the results of the changing our mix was going to have the effect it did and again, mostly I'd say April, we would have done things differently. And obviously, informed by that, we're making changes to our June and July plans to accommodate it.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: Yes, you'ev got 4 or 5 data points out there from people that have already reported. I'd be shocked if not everybody had some kind of bounce step change from fourth quarter to first quarter the absolute value of which depends on relatively strategy the sector that they are either and from a retail perspective but, I think, one of the things that were in the process of looking at this we have made a pretty dramatic shift from print and direct mail in the digital and that's definitely help drive the digital business very well. We may need to rethink that mix to rach some more of our traditional customers that get their information from print.

componenttext: Okay, and then on the economic front, you've got a lot of helpful details but we're struggling a little bit because the middle class has rising minimum wages, lower gas and somewhat good unemployment. componenttext: I wondered if you could talk a little bit more about the home category. Since that there was something that went with him but some things that are not these imprinted dramatic but you're not working other product cycle related from kind of called out the chocolate some other product circles and towards the end. So curious what's going on there for you guys? And then Wes, just planning initiatives what reconverted really good whole acquisition ever it makes a lot of sense for you guys. Wondering if you could share any sort of wins around the metrics and whether it be top end or kind of margin improvements that you're seeing from those efforts?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think from a localization perspective we've seen a slight sales us lift and certainly given the palms are not enough to drive their business and I suspect that the end of the spring will see a much improved margin in those categories. I think we m
componenttext: Sure. I think from a localization perspective we've seen a slight sales us lift and certainly given the palms are not enough to drive their business and I suspect that the end of the spring will see a much improved margin in those categories. I think we mentioned in the call we're up like 70% entering the quarter. The margin benefit since about 30% were just brought on board in the first quarter probably won't occur until the fall. So I think that will be back-end loaded but hopefully we can get some self benefits as we move throughout the year. The home business was difficult and in areas like kitchen electrics, I think, was category in electronics.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, what I'd say on the Home thing is the 2 things you always will got in-home the other, of course, you saw the 1 out which is product category performance and typically, in normal cases what we'll see is Home sort of moves together. And hard Home or
componenttext: Really, what I'd say on the Home thing is the 2 things you always will got in-home the other, of course, you saw the 1 out which is product category performance and typically, in normal cases what we'll see is Home sort of moves together. And hard Home or soft Home might be weaker stronger but sort of moves together. This quarter, there were definitely categories outperformance, underperformance us to a greater degree than normal. So we're still sort of going through all of that and trying to understand better why that would be. I don't know so much lifecycle related. There's certainly cases of that perhaps you're calling out may be user category might be one but that's a true of. But I think product cycle but more importantly, category performance were always dictate really critical look at. And the second 1, Home is more important than any category we sell by marketing. And so when our marketing is not as effective as it needs to be, our event strategy, our media mix strategy is not as effective as it needs to be. Home dramatically will distort that. And you will see it in the performance performances of the businesses, which basically means we're not reaching the core customer the way we need to reaching them. So I don't know that we decided one is more critical in terms of our underperformance in the first quarter and then the other. But I think that they both play a factor but I think that frankly, the event handles and pricing strategies probably played a bigger factor in the first quarter.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the things we try to make clear in the call about to be honest with you, Paul, is that right now, I think, we are having a hard time determining how much of our underperformance was more related to macro factors, which you're right, would have more
componenttext: One of the things we try to make clear in the call about to be honest with you, Paul, is that right now, I think, we are having a hard time determining how much of our underperformance was more related to macro factors, which you're right, would have more implication on future performance and how much is related more toward our company-specific factors, which could have to do with inventory carryover, could have to do with marketing and effectiveness particularly on events that critical times, could have to do with the transition because of weather, particularly in the Northeast and Midwest. I think we're still grappling a little bit with that. So we're definitely not in a position that we are putting on stake in the ground and say hey, this 1 is the big driver and therefore that means that this is for the rest of the year, I think, were just taking a in total transparency, these are all of the things that we see.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: If there are definitely some company-specific issues from a working perspective we're working on, rectifying so. So we know that, that affected our first quarter but I mean, I think, as you see more people report, I'd be shocked if anybody said he had a g
componenttext: If there are definitely some company-specific issues from a working perspective we're working on, rectifying so. So we know that, that affected our first quarter but I mean, I think, as you see more people report, I'd be shocked if anybody said he had a great March, April. We'll see. From an inventory perspective, I mean, one of the things that Michelle and the merchant and product development teams has been working very hard is increasing the incentives power receipts that are sourced faster. So one of the success stories has been our soul Brent we moved a lot more of the production to the 13 -- or 12 to 14 week lead time right in the order to get into the store. That's moved up from a percentage basis quite a bit. They comp midteens this quarter on a inventory reduction of a couple of 2%, same as the company. So we're trying to move more of our private and exclusive brands to that. Over the next couple of years, we want to move from 20% of that being sourced within that time frame to about 50% of our product. Some of the things don't to make much sense that are very cost sensitive and don't change a lot like men's cargo pants or a lot of the kids quote that you're looking for the absolute lowest price because that customer is so price sensitive. But many of our Lehmans Brent both in private and exclusive need to move more quickly to that fast fashion type of model and Michelle and the PT guys are driving very hard in doing that. So it's really the first example of that will do more of that as we will broadly or with brands like simply very, very well and Apartment 9 of moving into next year.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gentlemen, just follow up with the lower inventories coming, we're also to assume that, that tie to that would be less promotional stands that you guys take as you manage inventory down mid-singles for the second half?
componenttext: Gentlemen, just follow up with the lower inventories coming, we're also to assume that, that tie to that would be less promotional stands that you guys take as you manage inventory down mid-singles for the second half?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have to be aggressive in marketing because if you think about it possibility of test generally slower traffic in the sector, than the important thing is to take share. And so part of taking share has to do with certainly the amount of marketing
componenttext: I think we have to be aggressive in marketing because if you think about it possibility of test generally slower traffic in the sector, than the important thing is to take share. And so part of taking share has to do with certainly the amount of marketing you do and part of it has to do with selectively and thoughtfully applying good pricing strategies, value strategy. I mean, fundamentally, Paul, in the short term, if you're learning the business like ours, when you're faced with surprise because, I think, we're really surprised by the March, April underperformance. In the short term, you lower inventory, you lower expenses but you add marketing and drive value, that's what you do to change the trend of our business proactively. You can't wait and hope that things will get better and you have to sort of plan that things will continue this way and therefore, this way you do. In the Lahore term, than under things come into play and you start thinking about capital allocation and how much money you're spending but that's a much longer-term view. So we're doing the first part.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, we're going to be aggressive on promotional markdowns. Where we're going to save the money is on permanent markdowns that's what getting us into trouble over the last couple of years on margin perspective it's not because we of them room rem
componenttext: Yes, I think, we're going to be aggressive on promotional markdowns. Where we're going to save the money is on permanent markdowns that's what getting us into trouble over the last couple of years on margin perspective it's not because we of them room remote more than normal yet of this is up with way too much inventory. So we have plenty -- I know you and I probably never going to agree on this inventory thing, but we have plenty of room to reduce our inventory without affecting comp. We're so far from where we need to be and are going to do it measured over the next 5 years. But I think it's not that affect our ability to drive a comp. Getting people into the store is what's been a affect the ability to succeed from a comp perspective.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Brian Tunick with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Brian Tunick with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One is on digital. I think you guys said that digital grew midteens. I think you've originally talked about 20% growth rate so just curious on maybe what's happening there? Was that sort of slow down in the broader environment? Or was there
componenttext: Two questions. One is on digital. I think you guys said that digital grew midteens. I think you've originally talked about 20% growth rate so just curious on maybe what's happening there? Was that sort of slow down in the broader environment? Or was there a change in some marketing market tact? And from a margin perspective in digital, how you think about the profitability of your income business today the bricks-and-mortar business? And the second question on your store base, I guess the closing of these 18 stores, maybe what metrics will you be watching for us you think about what the right size of your store base should be, I guess, in this new world?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're pretty new to the story. So I've been early, I guess, realist on e-commerce and bricks-and-mortar. It's not profitable and I think everybody is coming around do that. Having said that, I think, we missed our plan slightly in the fellow was only on
componenttext: You're pretty new to the story. So I've been early, I guess, realist on e-commerce and bricks-and-mortar. It's not profitable and I think everybody is coming around do that. Having said that, I think, we missed our plan slightly in the fellow was only on a couple of days. I do think there is a material slowdown the same thing that affect traffic in the stores you don't need short you are not going to buy them only because it's easier and gunship to you for free. You buy it when you need it. I am not too worried about the spell from that perspective we kind of guided to 15% to 20% increase in our 3-year plan, and we saw the biggest increase last year in the back half. And I suspect that will be the case this year to us people find it more convenient in the fourth quarter to shop online. From a store base perspective, we closed every store really that had negative incremental free cash flow that's how we look at it. We've enclosed a few stores that were slightly positive. We needed to get a base of stores that was significant enough to see what happens to both online business and surrounding sister stores when we closed stores as well as what happens when we close a couple of stories in 1 particular market. So we've only closed part of the this year and probably 5 or 6 stories in my 13 years here so we didn't really have enough data points. We have the run the numbers as we move throughout the year and obviously if comps don't improved, and the store still be more stores that people what to negative cash flow, and we'll look at that on an annual basis. But for the most part, we have stores that are very much generating cash flow. I don't think you're going to see us close a significant number of stores every year. I think 18 was sort of starting plan, I think, it would be a lot lower than that if we decided to close stores for this year, for example.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well we look at performance over time, Dan. It's a really fundamentally, driven by actions that we take. So we always assume that whatever the underlying trend is, it's not going to change unless we do something to make it change. So we would never give y
componenttext: Well we look at performance over time, Dan. It's a really fundamentally, driven by actions that we take. So we always assume that whatever the underlying trend is, it's not going to change unless we do something to make it change. So we would never give you a forecast for the quarter or for the year based on some performance we have over the last 10 days the beginning of the quarter. It's always, driven by a look back into underperformance or sometimes overperformance and then actions we take. So they're usually tied together.

componenttext: It's like the time to the end of reporting periods. But we'll have a little better insight. I mean, I don't think there's going to be any big news in there. And I'm not going to be surprised if that was in more of the same in the first quarter because generally, you've heard some big retailers who have a large share in our categories report and they've had underperformance as well. So I don't think there's going to be any big news in there, I really don't.

componenttext: And my last question if I could just on product. You talked about the obviously had some activity this quarter with some brand launches and relaunches. componenttext: I would definitely expect to continue to talk about new brands coming on the store over the year. You kind of know well the time cycle on brand and introductions and the next to impossible to be able to share with you a new brand that would actually launch in the same year. componenttextpreview: All right. And then second you have at a macro clearly secular undercurrents are run on many of the we trust that your stores perhaps across the group is to persistent, how would you evaluate the potential need or even the potential benefits of consolidat
componenttext: All right. And then second you have at a macro clearly secular undercurrents are run on many of the we trust that your stores perhaps across the group is to persistent, how would you evaluate the potential need or even the potential benefits of consolidation as a strategic alternative?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, as a regular matter of business in our regular discussions at the board level, we're always looking at every single option that we have looking forward, Stephen. So there's nothing that's currently happened out in my mind that would accelera
componenttext: Well, I mean, as a regular matter of business in our regular discussions at the board level, we're always looking at every single option that we have looking forward, Stephen. So there's nothing that's currently happened out in my mind that would accelerate that discussion. And at the same time, there's nothing that's really happened that would decelerate it. I think it's always on the table. We generally have had a view that share in a categories that we operate in is really important. So having scale is an important factor to long-term success. And so right now, the plan that we've described to you gets us the scale by driving essentially our business organically. We certainly have these new tests, which heading have the possibility of paying off and things like our Off-Aisle concept or our outlet concept, the first one is with the Fila brand. And I still think that the small 35k [ph] store is going to be a meaningful contributor to our long-term performance. I don't know that, that particular store size will add a lot of growth but, I think, it will address what we both know is a really key factor right now, which is there's too much retail square footage. And so as some of our largest stores come up, we'd definitely be looking at our smaller store footprints as ways to continue to keep presence in the trade area but doing more productively. Hopefully that answers your question but there's nothing that's happening right now that we would share with you specifically around consolidation.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: That's very helpful. But are there any real charges that can be captured in consolidation from rationalizing the supply chain sort of a e-commerce platforms?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, usually, what you find on we probably kind of moving out of the discussion around our business into more strategic stuff. Probably dont' want to spend a lot of time on that. But generally, what we think on these things is given on a over-stored e
componenttext: Well, usually, what you find on we probably kind of moving out of the discussion around our business into more strategic stuff. Probably dont' want to spend a lot of time on that. But generally, what we think on these things is given on a over-stored environment and thinking about possibilities to grow that are additive on the top line, we'll probably going to put more focus on the cost line. So as we look at businesses, certainly if there's basis as we think can really improve our competencies in a particular category, we might consider it. But otherwise, if you're looking at scale, we're looking at places where we could take a lot of cost out of the business because, I think, that's just the right thing to do.

componenttext: Well, I mean, generally, I think, we characterize it as a success, for sure. I actually don't know the specifics on the online versus brick-and-mortars, Wes probably does. The apparel performance was a mix bag and so I think we've taken a look at that and trying to react accordingly. But I would definitely call it a big success. I mean, people have responded really well to the product. Fundamentally, the price points, which as you know, were more elevated have not been a factor at all in its success. So it does say to you that new ideas that are on target in spite of a general sales slump do well. They can do well.

componenttext: Yes, I think we always do a little on the online business where they get early access to new launches and things like that. So there's always a lot pretty big spike on that but I do think there's been any material difference between the 2 after we've had it shake out for a few months.

componenttext: Just a couple. First on loyalty, I think, the last time you gave a number there was back in the fall, 34 million members if I'm not mistaken. componenttextpreview: I think the loyalty numbers have definitely increased. I don't have up-to-date number in front of me but it's probably pushing close to 40 million. Some of those are duplicates, so not really unique people that we can measure because people like myself ha
componenttext: I think the loyalty numbers have definitely increased. I don't have up-to-date number in front of me but it's probably pushing close to 40 million. Some of those are duplicates, so not really unique people that we can measure because people like myself have multiple members on a card in the have different loyalty numbers associated with them. We never look for a year to bump one of the things that we're looking for and didn't implanter that in our path to the 21 billion that we've laid out a couple of years ago. So we really didn't build any into it as last year in the fourth quarter. We are making a concerted effort in the back half after we rolled out a new point-of-sale system to use the loyalty information is they've completed their profile to do a prescreened on them for our credit card and try to get people to move along the value path from not having a loyalty card to having a rewards card and and hopefully getting than them sign up for our credit card. So we'll have more to talk to you about it had probably at the end of the fourth quarter. the new point-of-sale system isn't rolling out until late in the third quarter so we would have a lot of data on that until after the holiday.

Such risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to, those that are described in Item 1A in Kohl's most recent annual report on Form 10-K and as may be supplemented from time to time in Kohl's other filings with the SEC, all of which are expressly incorporated herein by reference.
Also, please note that replays of this recording will not be updated. So if you're listening after May 12, 2016, it is possible that the information discussed is no longer current. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Wes McDonald, Chief Financial Officer of Kohl's Department Stores. Please go ahead.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. With me today is Kevin Mansell, our Chairman, CEO and President. I'll start today's call by walking through our operational results. Kevin will then provide more details on our Greatness Agenda initiatives, and then we'll take som
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. With me today is Kevin Mansell, our Chairman, CEO and President. I'll start today's call by walking through our operational results. Kevin will then provide more details on our Greatness Agenda initiatives, and then we'll take some of your questions.
Comp sales decrease 3.9% for the quarter. Transactions per store were down 4.8% for the quarter. Average transaction value increased 90 basis points comprised of 190 basis point increase in units per transaction and 100 basis points decrease in average unit retail.
From a line of business perspective, men's and women's were the strongest categories and home was the weakest. On a regional basis, the Northeast, Mid-Atlantic, Southeast and Midwest were the strongest. The West and South Central were the most difficult regions.
Gross margin decreased approximately 140 basis points for the quarter, about 10 basis points better than we guided to last quarter. Most of the margin decrease was due to clearance markdowns, taken the clear excess merchandise.
Our SG&A expenses decreased $8 million to $1 billion for the quarter. We effectively managed discretionary spending, but we're not able to leverage expenses on sales decrease. As a percentage of sales, SG&A deleveraged 75 basis points.
Store payroll dollars were slightly higher than last year as we pulled back on staffing to align with sales but did not leverage. Marketing deleveraged on higher spending associated with our Academy Awards sponsorship and higher digital spending. IT expenses also deleveraged.
Partially offsetting these increases were higher credit income and lower corporate expenses. Our credit share of sales was 58.8%, up 81 basis points from last year. Logistics expenses were also less than last year.
Depreciation expense was $234 million. The $7 million increase over last year is primarily due to higher IT amortization. Interest expense decreased $5 million to $79 million for the quarter. The decrease is due to favorable interest rates achieved during our $1.1 billion debt refinancing last summer.
Our income tax rate was 37.6%. The tax rate increased approximately 230 basis points as last year's first quarter included some favorable tax -- state tax audit settlements that we didn't have this year.
Net income on a reported GAAP basis for the quarter was $17 million and diluted earnings per share were $0.09. For the quarter, we reported $64 million of expenses related to the store closures and corporate restructuring that we announced earlier this year. The charge includes $53 million of impairment charges on the 18 stores, which we closed later this year. The remaining $11 million is primarily termination benefits for employees impacted by the closures and restructuring.
We expect to incur an additional $105 million to $110 million next quarter, which is slightly higher than our original estimates as we have more store associates than expected due to termination packages over relocation to another stories.
Substantially, all of next quarter's charge will be to record lease-related liabilities for stores we are closing prior to lease termination.
Excluding the store closures and restructuring charges, net income was $58 million and diluted earnings per share was $0.31 per share. We opened 3 new stores during the quarter, including our first 2 smaller 35,000 square foot format pilot stores. We currently operate 1,167 stores.
Gross square footage is 100.6 million square feet and selling square footage is 83.9 million square feet. We also open 2 Off-Aisle stores in the Milwaukee market. We ended quarter with $423 million of cash and cash equivalents, a decrease of $772 million from last year. 
Inventory dollars per store were 2% lower than the first quarter of 2015 consistent with our guidance of down low single-digits despite the challenging sales environment.
Units per store were essentially flat as increases in national brand were more than offset by decreases in private and exclusive brands. AP as a percent of inventory decreased 650 basis points to 32.9%. All of the decrease is due to lower receipts.
We also received some benefit in Q1 and Q2 of last year due to earlier-arriving receipts related to conservative planning after the port disruption in fall 2014 and spring 2015. Receipt flow year-over-year should be normalized by the third quarter of 2016. 
Capital expenditures were $177 million for the quarter, consistent with the first quarter of last year. Weighted average diluted shares were 184 million for the quarter. During the quarter, we repurchased 2.8 million shares of our stock. We ended the quarter with 185 million shares of stock outstanding.
On Wednesday, our board declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.50 per share. The dividend is payable on June 22 to shareholders of record on June 8. 
I'll note it over to Kevin, who will provide additional insights on our results.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Wes. The first quarter was well below our expectations in the sales line as a very strong start to the quarter in February was overcome by softer-than-expected pre-Easter business and then a further deterioration in April versus our plans. Our sea
componenttext:
Thanks, Wes. The first quarter was well below our expectations in the sales line as a very strong start to the quarter in February was overcome by softer-than-expected pre-Easter business and then a further deterioration in April versus our plans. Our seasonal business has followed the similar trajectory as the total company sales trend. 
A little more color on our sales. Men's and women's were better than the company with strength in active across both of those categories. Basic and dress clothing were relatively strong in men's but juniors and intimate were better in women's.
Kids, accessories and shoes were similar to the company with relative strength in boys and girls, beauty and fine jewelry as well as kid's shoes. Home was below the company with bedding, luggage and seasonal being outperformers with the balance being more difficult.
We did do a good job of managing our inventory, gross margin and expenses during the quarter. Our gross margin rate dropped 140 basis points versus our projection of 150 basis points of a drop due to better-than-planned promotional markdowns. Our inventory per store is now down 2%, in line with our expectations at the beginning of the year.
We continue to expect to make progress on inventory throughout this year. And we're targeting end the second quarter levels of down mid-single digits on a per-store basis.
On the SG&A line, every area of the company was able to pull back on their planned expenses to allow us to spend slightly less than last year in dollars versus our expectations originally of a 3% to 4% planned increase.
The team has shown agility to be able to pull back on expenses in a difficult sales environment. Now I'd like to take a few minutes to update you on some of the initiatives within the Greatness Agenda.
And our focus on product initiatives. Our national brands in the first quarter, we launched Stride Rite and kid's shoes and relaunched New Balance in the active area. The launch of Stride Rite helped kid's shoes to outperform and New Balance achieved a 19% comp in the quarter.
Our national brands in total were slightly positive on a comp basis but active and wellness leading the way with a mid-single-digit comp. Nike continues to be very strong, achieving a mid-teens comp in the quarter.
National brand penetration increased approximately 200 basis points in the quarter. We relaunched SONOMA in the first quarter and have been happy with the results in both men's and women's as they've seen improvements versus their priority trend.
During the quarter, we also launched Reed from Reed Krakoff's and handbags as improving our Accessories assortment has been a goal for us and it's off to a very good start.
Our localization efforts are proving out and 2016 will be the year that all of our planning efforts for unique assortments by store will come to life in 90% of our store fleet. As we enter the second quarter, approximately 70% of the assortment is now localized. We saw a modest lift in quarter 1 but would expect the effect of this to improve as we gain more experience and enter key transitional periods, like second and third quarter, where localized assortments should make a bigger impact.
In our focus around omnichannel initiatives, we continue to see strong results in digital demand with online generated demand achieving a mid-teens increase, as expected. We continue to invest in technology and training in our stores to allow us to Ship from Store and provide Buy Online, Pick Up In Store capabilities, providing faster shipping times and more convenience for our customer.
In the first quarter, Ship from Store was 15% of our online demand and Buy Online, Pick Up In Store was 3%. We believe we have a big opportunity there and we'll continue to test marketing that option throughout the year to make a top of mind in our customers for holiday.
Our Kohl's app was used by more than 12 million customers and growing. During the quarter, we added capability to use Apple Pay with our Kohl's Charge Card and our Yes2You Rewards loyalty program, becoming the first retailer to integrate its private-label charge card and loyalty program within Apple Pay.
On a store update front, we opened 2 small format stores during the quarter, and we have a lot of learnings already that we will incorporate into our fall plan openings. A big learning was you need to be flexible in our offerings as each trade area is unique due to the relatively small size of the trade areas and our smaller store size as well.
Localization we believe will be critical for our success in this initiative. We also opened 2 Off-Aisle stores in the Milwaukee area, one in the off-price center in one in a strip center. We're pleased to the initial results, and we'll monitor the effects on cannibalization, which we would expect be very small. And in late May, we'll open 12 Fila stores to gauge the possibilities in the outlet space.
Moving on to expenses. I mentioned in the year-end call that we're beginning an effort to reduce our leverage point on expenses from a 2% comparable sales increase to a 1.5% comparable sales increase. Despite the fact we're experiencing significant wage pressure in our stores and intend to continue to invest in our omnichannel initiatives, we feel more confident that we'll be able to achieve that goal.
I think, you can see that given our ability to manage expenses in the first quarter. We expect to find additional savings throughout the year that will allow us to achieve our expense goals.
In conclusion, it was definitely a difficult start to 2016. It's hard to gauge how much of the sales shortfall is related to macroeconomic factors and how much is related to company-specific factors. We're definitely focused on improving our sales but especially, our traffic to brick-and-mortar stores. We're relooking in all of our marketing vehicle to see where we can drive more business to the stores as well as ensuring our value message is particularly strong. Definitely not satisfied with the results so far, and we'll take -- action remain top of mind with the families that we serve. 
And with that, we'll be happy to take your questions.

componenttext: So what are you guys seeing from a promotional standpoint at the mid-tier out there, particularly how did your private-label performed? And while your inventories are in-line, do you see any need to be more aggressive with price to drag traffic?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, pricing, I mean, is definitely an element of our review in the comments that I made around marketing, Matt. Our private brands underperformed our national brands, the national brand penetration went up almost 200 basis points again. The trend line o
componenttext: Well, pricing, I mean, is definitely an element of our review in the comments that I made around marketing, Matt. Our private brands underperformed our national brands, the national brand penetration went up almost 200 basis points again. The trend line on some of the private brands, particularly SONOMA, definitely improved when we relaunched it. Pricing is always a big factor. I don't know that we would call out any particularly noticeable promotional effort by other retailers that I see having a major effect on how we're going to go to market. But when we think about improving the trend line from the disappointment in the first quarter to an improved number in the second quarter, we're definitely looking at pricing, we're definitely looking at marketing vehicles and the level of marketing we have to spend to get traction, particularly in our traffic and brick-and-mortar stores.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think it's less about price in the private brands and more about product. So we have some private brands that are doing very well, like so in our juniors area. Juniors continued its strength carried over from last fall, where other private
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think it's less about price in the private brands and more about product. So we have some private brands that are doing very well, like so in our juniors area. Juniors continued its strength carried over from last fall, where other private brands are a little tougher. So I think it's just a combination of both.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on a follow-up, on capital allocation, Wes, what's the minimum cash balance you're comfortable with on the balance sheet? And then just the best way to evaluate share repurchase versus I mean -- you mean almost a 5% dividend yield going f
componenttext: Got it. And then on a follow-up, on capital allocation, Wes, what's the minimum cash balance you're comfortable with on the balance sheet? And then just the best way to evaluate share repurchase versus I mean -- you mean almost a 5% dividend yield going forward?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the #1 priority for cash is to fund our growth, so we'll continue to invest in digital technologies and to drive that business. So our CapEx for this year is $825 million that remains the case. We want to -- we're committed to growing the di
componenttext: Well, I think the #1 priority for cash is to fund our growth, so we'll continue to invest in digital technologies and to drive that business. So our CapEx for this year is $825 million that remains the case. We want to -- we're committed to growing the dividend about 10% and the remainder of that would be left over for share repurchase. So we're still targeting $600 million for the year. We were little  [indiscernible] that this quarter. We'll take a look at our grid and put in a new grid and target the same $150 million for this quarter. For the end of the year, where we ended last year, I think it was around $700 million. That's about where we want to be. So I don't see any particular reason to go lower or higher than that. So given our projections, we would still be able to buy back $600 million this year.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Altschwager from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Altschwager from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the inventory. You did a nice job hitting your plans, however, given the much weaker-than-expected sales environment, it's still running and a bit ahead of comps. So I guess how much flexibility did you have to take a further step down on those re
componenttext: Just on the inventory. You did a nice job hitting your plans, however, given the much weaker-than-expected sales environment, it's still running and a bit ahead of comps. So I guess how much flexibility did you have to take a further step down on those receipts for the back half of the year, and then how should we do about that inventory progression?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the back half of the year is consistent with the second quarter. We would expect our inventories to be down mid-single digits on a per-store basis. So further reduction from where we are today and that's really going to be a function of buying les
componenttext: I think the back half of the year is consistent with the second quarter. We would expect our inventories to be down mid-single digits on a per-store basis. So further reduction from where we are today and that's really going to be a function of buying less receipts, which we've already planned and worked with our vendors on. So I suspect, absent any kind of change further downward, we should be able to hit those end of quarter goals.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the other thing I would add, Mark, is just there wasn't a lot to get very excited about it in that first quarter performance but one thing that, I think, the team did well and, I think, we're going to be well positioned. Regardless of where the bu
componenttext: I mean, the other thing I would add, Mark, is just there wasn't a lot to get very excited about it in that first quarter performance but one thing that, I think, the team did well and, I think, we're going to be well positioned. Regardless of where the business goes the remaining of the year is receipt flow and inventory, and we are down to last year, we're going to be down further than that as we go into third quarter. And they have demonstrated, I think, ability to be agile and bring on receipts is necessary. So that I think is a little bit of a bright spot.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a quick follow-up on SG&A. You addressed the longer-term leverage point. But how sustainable is this kind of down 1% run rate and should the negative comp environment continue over the next couple of quarters, just talk about the puts and takes t
componenttext: And then a quick follow-up on SG&A. You addressed the longer-term leverage point. But how sustainable is this kind of down 1% run rate and should the negative comp environment continue over the next couple of quarters, just talk about the puts and takes there?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our SG&A guidance like you saw was to leverage at 1.5 comp. I expect us I think that translated into like 1% to 2% dollars for the year if I recall correctly. We're going to have to be lower than the 1%, I think, we showed that we could do t
componenttext: Well, I think our SG&A guidance like you saw was to leverage at 1.5 comp. I expect us I think that translated into like 1% to 2% dollars for the year if I recall correctly. We're going to have to be lower than the 1%, I think, we showed that we could do that this quarter. It wasn't all just related to any one thing, as Kevin mentioned, every area of the company participated in bringing down their expenses. We have a lot of things underway to further reduce expenses that allowed us to get to that point and that will continue to see that come to fruition throughout the year. But my expectations for SG&A for the year would be somewhere between flat to up 1%. So I think we can take it down a level from where we are today.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: And next will go to Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: You had previously guided to a 0 to 1% comp for the year, is that still on the table? And can you just discuss the biggest drivers to try to turn that trend around over the next few quarters?
