headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Plus or minus to half and the comp was flat to 1%.
componenttext: Plus or minus to half and the comp was flat to 1%.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Which as Wes said was essentially flat total a modest increase on a comp basis and also EPS. The first quarter, as you know, Lorraine is a really small percentage of the total year, both on a sales basis but, in particular, on an EPS basis. I think for th
componenttext: Which as Wes said was essentially flat total a modest increase on a comp basis and also EPS. The first quarter, as you know, Lorraine is a really small percentage of the total year, both on a sales basis but, in particular, on an EPS basis. I think for the fourth quarter, our expected earnings per share was probably around $0.40, which would be less than 10% of the annual expectation that we gave. So we're really just barely into the year. For us to look forward and make some forecast change based on a really sharp percentage of the year and a very small percentage of that total, I think, it'd just be wrong. We are obviously making plans for being more defensive around things, as Wes said, like inventory or like expenses to be prepared to bring down. But we still feel good that the sales trend will improve in the second quarter, and we definitely feel like it will improve further as we go into the back half.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what are the reasons behind the good feelings around comp improving?
componenttext: And what are the reasons behind the good feelings around comp improving?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think on a comp basis, we've kind of articulated them in the beginning of the year guidance. One of the big things that you know that hurt us in the third and fourth quarter last year was a buildup in inventory that really took away all of our fle
componenttext: Well, I think on a comp basis, we've kind of articulated them in the beginning of the year guidance. One of the big things that you know that hurt us in the third and fourth quarter last year was a buildup in inventory that really took away all of our flexibility to adjust receipts into categories that were outperforming other areas. And so one of the big things, I think, Wes and I both really feel about is our inventory position puts us in a space where we can see the businesses that are performing. We do have some businesses that are outperforming other businesses in spite of lower traffic levels, particularly lower traffic levels in March and April. We have categories that are actually doing well. With talked about some of those, and so we want to be in a role where we can feed those. I don't know if you want to add anything, Wes?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think, our expectation for the rest of the year would be flat to 1% for the remaining quarter. So That when you do the math, you guys are smart, that probably puts you toward the lower end of the comp range just may be even a little bit bel
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think, our expectation for the rest of the year would be flat to 1% for the remaining quarter. So That when you do the math, you guys are smart, that probably puts you toward the lower end of the comp range just may be even a little bit below, which is why we think that we need to take our expenses down to achieve the earnings guidance that we gave. As Kevin mentioned, it's less than 10% of our expectations for the earnings for the year, so we feel like there's a lot of room in front of it that we can do different things to try to make that earnings.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then is there any little room [ph] on the CapEx that are places that you could potentially cut to help improve the cash flow that way?
componenttext: Great. And then is there any little room [ph] on the CapEx that are places that you could potentially cut to help improve the cash flow that way?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that would be more likely to try to put the screws to the inventor a little bit more. We have to invest for a little long term. Much like Macy's reported yesterday, we had a very strong February with the first positive comp we've run since 201
componenttext: No, I think that would be more likely to try to put the screws to the inventor a little bit more. We have to invest for a little long term. Much like Macy's reported yesterday, we had a very strong February with the first positive comp we've run since 2011 then we saw a pretty dramatic drop-off the same timing that they mentioned. So we'll have to see if that drop-off is a macro induced [ph] thing or if it's company-specific. We'll know a lot more as more companies report later this week. But it will get warm. We have shorts to sell, and we're in a good inventory position. So I think at some point, people will need those clothes and will combine them.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean the area, I think, Wes and I both agree the areas that are probably getting more scrutiny. I know now they did necessarily impact this year's actual capital expenditure but looking out this year through year 2 and year 3 forward, are probably CapEx
componenttext: I mean the area, I think, Wes and I both agree the areas that are probably getting more scrutiny. I know now they did necessarily impact this year's actual capital expenditure but looking out this year through year 2 and year 3 forward, are probably CapEx around technology, Wes, is definitely getting more scrutiny from us as we look at whether or not the investments we're making are giving us the return that we expected to get from them. And the second thing is definitely capital that's dedicated towards fulfillment of our online generated demand regardless of whether that capital is in our stores or that capital is in technology or that capital is in a fulfillment center either existing or future to come. Those 2 are probably reason to the top in terms of areas we're looking at.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes.
componenttext: Yes. Yes.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Trussell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Trussell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to discuss a little bit further, the composition and cadence of the comp. I believe in the fourth quarter and generally through 2015, transactions per store were roughly flattish. And so given the down 4.8 this quarter and the solid start in F
componenttext: Just wanted to discuss a little bit further, the composition and cadence of the comp. I believe in the fourth quarter and generally through 2015, transactions per store were roughly flattish. And so given the down 4.8 this quarter and the solid start in February, is it fair to assume that you are exiting the quarter those last 4 or 5 weeks kind of down 8%, 9%, 10%? And if so, maybe you give a little bit more detail on those season -- the seasonal goods performance specifically, Wes, I know you mentioned whether that, that shorts weren't selling. So maybe you can give us a little bit more of a handle on what kind of bounce back you might expect if the weather does warm up? And then lastly on the comp, AUR was down 100 basis points. Wes, do you expect that to be just unique to the first quarter given the aggressive promotions?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, those are a lot of questions for a one, but I'll try to answer most of for them. They are down mostly from the clearance side. I would expect that to be a onetime phenomenon in the first quarter. Your math on the comp for the balance of the quarter w
componenttext: Yes, those are a lot of questions for a one, but I'll try to answer most of for them. They are down mostly from the clearance side. I would expect that to be a onetime phenomenon in the first quarter. Your math on the comp for the balance of the quarter wasn't correct but you were directionally correct. If you're positive in the first month, you've got to be negative in the last 2. From a seasonal perspective, our spring seasonal goods were good in February, poor in March and April kind of consistent with the comps. They were worse than the company by a couple of hundred basis points. It's a fairly significant part of the business but as we mentioned, home was the worst category, which wouldn't have as much seasonality to it. We've got to improve traffic, that's somewhat of a marketing issue that we've got to try to resolve. It also relates to product once we get them into store, our conversion rates are actually improved, we just have to get them into the store.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, just to be clear on one thing, as we look at drivers of comp, whether they are periods of positive comp we have or periods of negative comp like the first quarter, we try to prioritize in our minds that what the drivers are so we can attack those. T
componenttext: Paul, just to be clear on one thing, as we look at drivers of comp, whether they are periods of positive comp we have or periods of negative comp like the first quarter, we try to prioritize in our minds that what the drivers are so we can attack those. Things like seasonal category performance, which weather often drives that, we don't think is at the top of the priority list in terms of things that were a driver of negative comp in the first quarter. Our seasonal categories underperformed for sure but they didn't significantly underperform. So I don't think Wes does either, put them at the very top. We put things at the top, I think, we mentioned there seems to be some more macro issue given performances of both ourselves and competition. There seems to be some change in consumer behavior in terms of traffic coming into our stores, maybe because of that. We definitely have opportunity in our marketing area to improve our effectiveness. As we've moved in our media mix from a more traditional hold media mix to a much more future state. We're finding things that haven't worked as well that are probably going to have to be course corrected in the near term to get a better result. And then eventually, as you get down to seasonal categories and we look at it and say yes, the seasonal categories, which are very significant percent of our total business, underperformed. And if they performed as normal, we would have been a lot better. But I don't put it at the top.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful color. Lastly, from me. You stated that the comp guidance remains flat to 1% for the balance of the year. You modestly adjusted SG&A dollar growth. I think to now kind of more flat to up 1% for the balance of the year. Just on the gros
componenttext: That's very helpful color. Lastly, from me. You stated that the comp guidance remains flat to 1% for the balance of the year. You modestly adjusted SG&A dollar growth. I think to now kind of more flat to up 1% for the balance of the year. Just on the gross margins, Wes, flat to up 20%, is that still attainable in your view? And if so, should we may be push a little bit more towards the third and fourth quarter as opposed to 2Q, just given the channel still seeing some traffic weakness or just help us out on the gross margins.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean before Wes mentions anything himself, I would just tell you, Paul, just to be clear. We're not updating anything. We're not updating ourselves. We're not updating our margin. We're not updating our SG&A. We're definitely not updating our earnings.
componenttext: I mean before Wes mentions anything himself, I would just tell you, Paul, just to be clear. We're not updating anything. We're not updating ourselves. We're not updating our margin. We're not updating our SG&A. We're definitely not updating our earnings. The first quarter is a small percentage of the year, and there is not enough information we see to put us in a position where we feel that we could knowledgeably tell you some type of update. We're just sort of targeting you to areas in which we're going to put more effort. And naturally, if you have a disappointment at the beginning of the year in sales, one area that's going to bubble up, and we've got to put a lot more effort around is expense control and bringing down our ability to bring down expenses. Another area naturally is inventory. And ensuring that we not only can meet the lower levels of inventory we had planned going into the second and third quarter, but actually give ourselves ability to even bring it down further. So this -- I realize to some extent maybe it's nuance but, I think, it's an important distinction so we're trying to be a transparent and these are the things we're doing in response to what we are seeing but there is no update to anything.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the margin, I mean, I think, we said in the beginning of the year, we have more opportunity in the back half for gross margin improvement, just given by our poor performance in the fourth quarter, that remains the same.
componenttext: And in terms of the margin, I mean, I think, we said in the beginning of the year, we have more opportunity in the back half for gross margin improvement, just given by our poor performance in the fourth quarter, that remains the same.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just as you do look back to this quarter, could you brief us on any things you might have done differently if that was possible? And then does this tweak in terms of how you think about the broader Greatness Agenda just as you think about your strategic p
componenttext: Just as you do look back to this quarter, could you brief us on any things you might have done differently if that was possible? And then does this tweak in terms of how you think about the broader Greatness Agenda just as you think about your strategic plans? Also, on the traffic situation and regarding the softer pre-Easter and then April, what -- did you have any sense of if it was a different -- if it was a specific demographic? Was there something going on with a younger generation versus older in terms of thinking about where you are more sensitive and losing traffic?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can probably try to take a wack, I'll cover the first part and Wes can talk to you about the traffic drivers. On the -- essentially, I think, what you're asking is, are there different actions you would have made had you known what was coming in terms o
componenttext: I can probably try to take a wack, I'll cover the first part and Wes can talk to you about the traffic drivers. On the -- essentially, I think, what you're asking is, are there different actions you would have made had you known what was coming in terms of traffic into your stores. And I kind of view that in the short-term and the long-term. On the long-term, right now, we actually feel pretty confident that the things we're working on are the right things and they remain the right things. Clearly, speed to get to where we want to be in our plan on those actions needs to be accelerated. We got to get there faster, there is no question about that. Emphasis might change. So we typically midyear kind of review our long-term plan and our moves underneath the Greatness Agenda, and we might emphasize more one move versus another based on what we're seeing. But I think fundamentally, we still feel very confident about the plan that the plan is the right plan and our actions are the right actions. In the short term, I think, Wes and I both say, I think, we wish that some of our event handles and efforts were better. If we had known that there was going to be a macro traffic issue and, in particular, I would say in April and had we known that some of the results of the change in our remix was going to have the effect it did. And again, mostly I'd say April, we would have done things differently. And obviously, informed by that, we're making changes to our June and July plans to accommodate it.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, you got 4 or 5 data points out there from people that have already reported. I'd be shocked if not everybody had some kind of a down step change from fourth quarter to first quarter the absolute value of which depends on relatively strength o
componenttext: Yes, I mean, you got 4 or 5 data points out there from people that have already reported. I'd be shocked if not everybody had some kind of a down step change from fourth quarter to first quarter the absolute value of which depends on relatively strength of the sector that they are in, and from a retail perspective but, I think, one of the things we're in the process of looking at this. We have made a pretty dramatic shift from print and direct mail into digital, that's definitely help drive the digital business very well. We may need to rethink that mix to reach some more of our traditional customers that get their information from print.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and on the economic front, you gave a lot of the helpful details, but we're struggling a little bit because the middle class has rising minimum wages, lower gas and somewhat good unemployment. So how do you help us reconcile or is just very puzzling
componenttext: Okay, and on the economic front, you gave a lot of the helpful details, but we're struggling a little bit because the middle class has rising minimum wages, lower gas and somewhat good unemployment. So how do you help us reconcile or is just very puzzling in terms of those trends versus what we're seeing in retail at large.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: They're not buying apparel, I mean that's a simple answer I think, they're spending money on [indiscernible]. I've read some of your notes, I agree with them. They're spending money on restaurants and experiences until we get some more excitement apparel.
componenttext: They're not buying apparel, I mean that's a simple answer I think, they're spending money on [indiscernible]. I've read some of your notes, I agree with them. They're spending money on restaurants and experiences until we get some more excitement apparel. There -- it's going to be remained, in my opinion, a replenishment market.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next available to Neely Tamminga with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And next available to Neely Tamminga with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the home category. Since like there were some things that win -- are winning but some things that are not, and it seem pretty dramatic that they're not working, are they product cycle related
componenttext: Kevin, just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the home category. Since like there were some things that win -- are winning but some things that are not, and it seem pretty dramatic that they're not working, are they product cycle related? Even we've heard from [indiscernible] who's kind of called out [indiscernible] and some other product cycles seem to be towards the end. So curious what's going on there for you guys? And then Wes, on the  assortment planning initiatives, which you think are  really can -- the whole acquisition effort makes a lot of sense for you guys. Wondering if you could share any sort of wins around the metrics and whether it be top end or kind of margin improvements that you're seeing from those efforts?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think from a localization perspective, we've seen a slight sales lift, certainly given our comps not enough to drive the business, and I suspect that the end of the spring will see a much improved margin in those categories. I think we mentioned i
componenttext: Sure. I think from a localization perspective, we've seen a slight sales lift, certainly given our comps not enough to drive the business, and I suspect that the end of the spring will see a much improved margin in those categories. I think we mentioned in the call we're up like 70% entering the quarter. The margin benefit since about 30% were just brought on board in the first quarter, probably won't occur until the fall. So I think that will be back-half loaded but hopefully, we can get some sales benefits as we move throughout the year. The home business was difficult and areas like kitchen electrics, I think, was a tough category in electronics.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, what I'd say on the Home thing is the 2 things you always look at in a home are always, of course, you saw the one out which is product category performance and typically, in normal cases what we'll see is Home sort of moves together. And hard Hom
componenttext: Really, what I'd say on the Home thing is the 2 things you always look at in a home are always, of course, you saw the one out which is product category performance and typically, in normal cases what we'll see is Home sort of moves together. And hard Home or soft Home might be weaker or stronger but it sort of moves together. This quarter, there were definitely categories outperforms, underperformances to a greater degree than normal. So we're still sort of going through all of that and trying to understand better why that would be. I don't know there is so much lifecycle related. There's certainly cases of that perhaps you're calling out may be user category might be one but that's a true of. But I think product cycle but more importantly, category performance we'll always take a really critical look at. And the second one is, Home is more impacted than any category we sell by marketing. And so when our marketing is not as effective as it needs to be, our event strategy, our media mix strategy is not as effective as it needs to be. Home dramatically will distort that. And you will see it in the performances of the businesses, which basically means we're not reaching the core customer in the way we need to reach them. So I don't know that we've decided one is more critical in terms of our underperformance in the first quarter than the other. But I think that they both play a factor but I think that frankly, the event handles and pricing strategies probably played a bigger factor in the first quarter.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Lejuez from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Lejuez from Citi.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you guys are leaving the door open that there may be some sort of a bigger picture macro issue going on, so just curious if that is the case, if that is the consideration why the assumption that comps improved from what we saw in the first
componenttext: It sounds like you guys are leaving the door open that there may be some sort of a bigger picture macro issue going on, so just curious if that is the case, if that is the consideration why the assumption that comps improved from what we saw in the first quarter. And I guess additionally, I'm just trying to tie that still together with -- as inventories come down, it seems like it'd be a little bit more of a challenge to drive comps. So just trying to tie that together. I think you guys have had examples where you've been able to turn faster. If you could may be just share those with us and help connect those dots.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Wes will talk about the last part of it.
componenttext: Well, Wes will talk about the last part of it.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's question. He just really wants to stake [indiscernible] on the inventory, so...
componenttext: Yes, that's question. He just really wants to stake [indiscernible] on the inventory, so...

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the -- one of the things we try to make clear in the call, to be honest with you, Paul, is that right now, I think, we are having a hard time determining how much of our underperformance was more related to macro factors, which you're right, would have
componenttext: On the -- one of the things we try to make clear in the call, to be honest with you, Paul, is that right now, I think, we are having a hard time determining how much of our underperformance was more related to macro factors, which you're right, would have more implication on future performance and how much is related more to our company-specific factors, which could have to do with inventory carryover, could have to do with marketing and effectiveness particularly on events that critical times, could have to do with the transition because of weather, particularly in the Northeast and Midwest. I think we're still grappling a little bit with that. So we're definitely not in a position that we are stake -- putting the stake in the ground and say hey, this one is the big driver and therefore that means that this is for the rest of the year, I think, we're just saying, a, in total transparency, these are all of the things we see.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there are definitely some company-specific issues from a working perspective that we're working on rectifying. So we know that, that affected our first quarter but I mean, I think, as you see more people report, I'd be shocked if anybody said they ha
componenttext: Yes, there are definitely some company-specific issues from a working perspective that we're working on rectifying. So we know that, that affected our first quarter but I mean, I think, as you see more people report, I'd be shocked if anybody said they had a great March, April. We'll see. from an inventory perspective, I mean, one of the things that Michelle and the merchant and product development teams has been working very hard is increasing the percentage of our receipts that are sourced faster. So one of the success stories has been our SO brand where we've moved a lot more of the production to the 13 -- or 12 to 14 week lead time from right in the order to get into the store. That's moved up from a percentage basis quite a bit. They comp mid-teens this quarter on a inventory reduction of a couple of 2%, same as the company. So we're trying to move more of our private and exclusive brands to that. Over the next couple of years, we want to move from 20% of that being sourced within that time frame to about 50% of our product. Some of the things don't make much sense that are very cost sensitive and don't change a lot like men's cargo pants or a lot of the kids quote that you're looking for the absolute lowest price because that customer is so price sensitive. But many of our women's brands, both in private and exclusive need to move more quickly to that fast fashion type of model and Michelle and the PT guys are driving very hard in doing that. So it's really the first example of that will do more of that as we move throughout the year with brands like imply Vera Vera Wang and Apartment 9 and move into next year.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gentlemen, just a follow-up with the lower inventories coming, we're also to assume that, that tie to that would be less promotional stands that you guys take as you manage inventory down mid-singles for the second half?
componenttext: Gentlemen, just a follow-up with the lower inventories coming, we're also to assume that, that tie to that would be less promotional stands that you guys take as you manage inventory down mid-singles for the second half?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we need to be aggressive on marketing because if you think about the possibility of just generally slower traffic in the sector, than the important thing is to take share. And so part of taking share has to do with certainly the amount of marketin
componenttext: I think we need to be aggressive on marketing because if you think about the possibility of just generally slower traffic in the sector, than the important thing is to take share. And so part of taking share has to do with certainly the amount of marketing you do and part of it has to do with selectively and thoughtfully applying good pricing strategies, value strategies. I mean, fundamentally, Paul, in the short term, if you're running the business like ours, when you're faced with a surprise because, I think, we really were surprised by the March, April underperformance. In the short term, you lower inventory, you lower expenses but you add marketing and drive value, that's what you do to change the trend of our business proactively. You can't wait and hope that things will get better, and you have to sort of plan that things will continue this way and therefore, this is the way to do in a longer term than other things come into play and you start thinking about capital allocation and how much money you're spending but that's a much longer-term view. So we're doing the first part.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, we're going to be aggressive on promotional markdowns. Where we're going to save the money is on the permanent markdowns that's what gotten us into trouble over the last couple of years from a gross margin perspective, it's not because we've
componenttext: Yes, I think, we're going to be aggressive on promotional markdowns. Where we're going to save the money is on the permanent markdowns that's what gotten us into trouble over the last couple of years from a gross margin perspective, it's not because we've had to promote more than normal as we've ended this season with way too much inventory. So we have plenty -- I know you and I probably never going to agree on this inventory thing, but we have plenty of room to reduce our inventory without affecting comp. We're so far from where we need to be and are going to do it measured over the next 5 years. But I think it's not going to affect our ability to drive a comp. Getting people into the store is what's going to affect the ability to succeed from a comp perspective.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Brian Tunick with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Brian Tunick with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One is on digital. I think you guys said that digital grew mid-teens. I think you've originally talked about 20% growth rate so just curious on maybe what was happening there? Was that just sort of a slowdown in the broader environment? Or
componenttext: Two questions. One is on digital. I think you guys said that digital grew mid-teens. I think you've originally talked about 20% growth rate so just curious on maybe what was happening there? Was that just sort of a slowdown in the broader environment? Or was there a change in some marketing tact? And from a margin perspective in digital, how do you think about the profitability of your income business today versus bricks-and-mortar business? And the second question on your store base, I guess the closing of these 18 stores, maybe what metrics will you be watching for us you think about what the right size of your store base should be, I guess, in this new world?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're pretty new to the story. So I've been early, I guess, realist on e-commerce and bricks-and-mortar. It's not as profitable and I think everybody is coming around do that. Having said that, I think, we missed our plan slightly in digital, it was only
componenttext: You're pretty new to the story. So I've been early, I guess, realist on e-commerce and bricks-and-mortar. It's not as profitable and I think everybody is coming around do that. Having said that, I think, we missed our plan slightly in digital, it was only on a couple of days. I don't think there is a material slowdown, the same things that affect traffic in the stores. You don't need short you are not going to buy them online just because it's easier and could shift to your house for free. You buy it when you need it. So I think that's I am not too worried about digital from that perspective. We kind of guided to 15% to 20% increase in our 3-year plan, and we saw the biggest increase last year in the back half. And I suspect that will be the case this year too as people find it more convenient in the fourth quarter to shop online. From a store base perspective, we closed every store really that had negative incremental free cash flow that's how we look at it. We even closed a few stores that were slightly positive. We needed to get a base of stores that was significant enough to see what happens to both online business and surrounding sister stores when we closed stores, as well as what happens when we close a couple of stories in one particular market. So we've only closed prior to this year, I mean, probably 5 or 6 stories in my 13 years here, so we didn't really have enough data points. We have to run the numbers as we move throughout the year, obviously if comps don't improved, in the stores there will be more stores that tip over to negative cash flow, and we'll look at that on an annual basis. But for the most part, we have stores that are very much generating cash flow. I don't think you're going to see us close a significant number of stores every year. I think 18 was sort of starting plan, I think, it would be a lot lower than that if we decided to close stores for this year, for example.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we're going to Dan Binder with Jefferies.
componenttext: Next, we're going to Dan Binder with Jefferies.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is regarding your comments earlier about expecting improvement in Q2, and I was just wondering if that was in part based on what you're seeing in the last couple of weeks?
componenttext: My question is regarding your comments earlier about expecting improvement in Q2, and I was just wondering if that was in part based on what you're seeing in the last couple of weeks?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we look at performance over time, Dan. It's really, fundamentally driven by actions that we take. So we always assume that whatever the underlying trend is, it's not going to change unless we do something to make it change. So we would never give yo
componenttext: Well, we look at performance over time, Dan. It's really, fundamentally driven by actions that we take. So we always assume that whatever the underlying trend is, it's not going to change unless we do something to make it change. So we would never give you a forecast for the quarter or for the year based on some performance we had over the last 10 days or beginning of the quarter. It's always, driven by a look back into underperformance or sometimes overperformance and then actions we take. So they're usually tied together.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: That said, has there been some sequential improvement in the last couple of weeks?
componenttext: That said, has there been some sequential improvement in the last couple of weeks?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: We never talk about performance inside the quarter, Dan.
componenttext: We never talk about performance inside the quarter, Dan.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I thought I'd try. My second question is with regard to this market share. I know you've talked about, Wes, Amazon I guess showing up in the top 10 on apparel now and maybe towards the bottom of the list. I'm just curious as you look at market share data,
componenttext: I thought I'd try. My second question is with regard to this market share. I know you've talked about, Wes, Amazon I guess showing up in the top 10 on apparel now and maybe towards the bottom of the list. I'm just curious as you look at market share data, recognizing that you and others were soft. How does your individual market share data look for different categories that you're selling?

componenttext: It will be a little better informed on that, Dan, and probably about a month that share data is...

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's on a lab.
componenttext: It's on a lab.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we're not as tightly timed to the end of reporting periods. But we'll have a little better insight. I mean, I don't think there's going to be any big news in there. I think I suspect companies who are given up more share in particular categories will c
componenttext: If we're not as tightly timed to the end of reporting periods. But we'll have a little better insight. I mean, I don't think there's going to be any big news in there. I think I suspect companies who are given up more share in particular categories will continue to give up more share. We have been able to hold our share but not gain in our share. And I'm not going to be surprised if that wasn't more of the same in the first quarter because generally, you've heard some big retailers who have a large share in our categories report and they've had underperformance as well. So I don't think there's going to be any big news in there, I really don't.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my last question if I could just on product. You talked about [indiscernible] you've obviously had some activity this quarter with some brand launches and relaunches. Can you give us a sense as to whether or not there are new national brands if you ca
componenttext: And my last question if I could just on product. You talked about [indiscernible] you've obviously had some activity this quarter with some brand launches and relaunches. Can you give us a sense as to whether or not there are new national brands if you can talk about specifics if there are more that you expect to announce this year? And what other product new launches you may expect over the balance of the year as well?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I definitely would expect to continue to be able to talk about new brands coming into the store over the year. You kind of know well the lifetime cycle on brand introductions and the next to impossible to be able to share with you a new brand that would a
componenttext: I definitely would expect to continue to be able to talk about new brands coming into the store over the year. You kind of know well the lifetime cycle on brand introductions and the next to impossible to be able to share with you a new brand that would actually launch in the same year. So any news we have on brand launches coming, and I do expect that there will be some, will really impact our 2017 performance.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 follow-ups I guess on Brian's questions earlier, first, what amount of sales recapture from the closed stores are you factoring in your guidance?
componenttext: I have 2 follow-ups I guess on Brian's questions earlier, first, what amount of sales recapture from the closed stores are you factoring in your guidance?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Factored 0 in it.
componenttext: Factored 0 in it.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then second you highlighted these macro concerns, in fact, in traffic but there are certainly some secular undercurrents around online. If the weak traffic of your stores and perhaps across the group is to persistent, how would you evaluate
componenttext: All right. And then second you highlighted these macro concerns, in fact, in traffic but there are certainly some secular undercurrents around online. If the weak traffic of your stores and perhaps across the group is to persistent, how would you evaluate the potential need or even the potential benefits from consolidation as a strategic alternative?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we're -- as a regular matter of business in our regular discussions at the board level, we're always looking at every single option that we have looking forward, Stephen. So there's nothing that's currently happened out in my mind would acce
componenttext: Well, I mean, we're -- as a regular matter of business in our regular discussions at the board level, we're always looking at every single option that we have looking forward, Stephen. So there's nothing that's currently happened out in my mind would accelerate that discussion. And at the same time, there's nothing that's really happened that would decelerate it. I think it's always on the table. We generally have had a view that share in categories that we operate in is really important. So having scale is an important factor to long-term success. And so right now, the plan that we've described to you gets us the scale by driving essentially our business organically. We certainly have these new tests, which I think have the possibility of paying off and things like our Off-Aisle concept or our outlet concept, the first one is with the Fila brand. And I still think that the small 35k store is going to be a meaningful contributor to our long-term performance. I don't know that, that particular store size will add a lot of growth but, I think, it will address what we both know is a really key factor right now, which is there's too much retail square footage. And so as some of our largest stores come up, we'd definitely be looking at our smaller store footprints as ways to continue to keep presence in the trade area but do it more productively. Hopefully, that answers your question but there's nothing that's happening right now that we would share with you specifically around consolidation.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. But are kind of real synergies that could be captured in consolidation from rationalizing the supply chain store base and e-commerce platforms?
componenttext: That's very helpful. But are kind of real synergies that could be captured in consolidation from rationalizing the supply chain store base and e-commerce platforms?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, usually, what you find on that we're probably kind of moving out of the discussion around our business into more strategic stuff. Probably dont' want to spend a lot of time on that. But generally, what we think on these things is given a over-sto
componenttext: Well, usually, what you find on that we're probably kind of moving out of the discussion around our business into more strategic stuff. Probably dont' want to spend a lot of time on that. But generally, what we think on these things is given a over-stored environment and thinking about possibilities to grow that are additive on the top line, we probably are going to put more focus on the cost line. So as we look at businesses, certainly if there's businesses we think can really improve our competencies in a particular category, we might consider it. But otherwise, if we're looking at scale, we're looking at places where we could take a lot of cost out of the business because, I think, that's just the right thing to do.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: A follow-on question. Regarding the content of the inventory, obviously, dollars are down. Are you guys convinced the balance is correct national brands to private label? headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: It always helps to sell more seasonal goods earlier in the season than it does some later. You know that really well. So having a little less seasonal goods is always a good thing, but we actually do have less seasonal goods in the last year. So I think w
componenttext: It always helps to sell more seasonal goods earlier in the season than it does some later. You know that really well. So having a little less seasonal goods is always a good thing, but we actually do have less seasonal goods in the last year. So I think we're positioned well but I get it, there's no other answer than to say, hey, if you've had a tough seasonal performance in the first quarter, isn't it nice to have a lot less going into the second quarter? Yes, of course, it is. But we just have to deal with what we have right now. It's not a big factor. I think Wes probably know that.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I mean we bought spring receipts down to 9%. So I feel comfortable that we'll be in a good inventory position at the end of the second quarter unless we see a step change down from where we ramp.

componenttext: Kevin, can you talk a little bit about the launch of the Reed business? I guess what you've learned in stores versus online, the different categories, handbags versus clothing, price points at this point so far?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, generally, I think, we characterize it as a success, for sure. I actually don't know the specifics on the online versus brick-and-mortars, Wes probably does. I think generally, and probably not surprising to you that handbags performance was
componenttext: Well, I mean, generally, I think, we characterize it as a success, for sure. I actually don't know the specifics on the online versus brick-and-mortars, Wes probably does. I think generally, and probably not surprising to you that handbags performance was really good. The apparel performance was a mix bag and so I think we're taking a look at that and trying to react accordingly. But I would definitely call it a big success. I mean, people have responded really well to the product. Fundamentally, in the price points, which as you know, were more elevated have not been a factor at all in its success. So it does say to you that new ideas that are on target in spite of a general sales slump do well. They can do well.

componenttext: Yes, I think we always do a little thing with on the online business where they get early access to launches and things like that. So there's always a lot -- a pretty big spike on that but I do think there's been a material difference between the 2 after you've had it shake out for a few months.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I like the fact you have a sense of humor, Bob, in a tough environment. Women's active is really good. Trying to put a more serious note on that. Women's active I think is really good and continues to be good just like active in general is good. The categ
componenttext: I like the fact you have a sense of humor, Bob, in a tough environment. Women's active is really good. Trying to put a more serious note on that. Women's active I think is really good and continues to be good just like active in general is good. The category in women's I think that outperformed significantly and Wes can jump in, but it's our Juniors business. There was a big outperformance in juniors in the first quarter. And that business, we didn't want to get into this on the call because it's relatively a short period of time and a small percentage of our total women's business but that business has implemented a new supply chain strategy to move much more quickly on product. And, I think, it is definitely benefiting them in a huge way. And so that's a learning that we're incorporating into other areas as well. I don't know if you want to add anything on there, Wes?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple. First on loyalty, I think, the last time you gave a number that was back in the fall, 34 million members if I'm not mistaken. So just wondered where that number stands currently? And what you're seeing in terms of the impact on the business from the loyalty program? And does that I mean, I know you talked about tweaking the marketing and tweaking the program. Have you done much there? And does that just factor into the view that same-store sales will start to improve a bit from here through the balance of the year?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the loyalty numbers have definitely increased. I don't have up-to-date number in front of me but it's probably pushing close to 40 million. Some of those are duplicates, so not real unique people that we can measure because people like myself have
componenttext: I think the loyalty numbers have definitely increased. I don't have up-to-date number in front of me but it's probably pushing close to 40 million. Some of those are duplicates, so not real unique people that we can measure because people like myself have multiple members on a card and they have different loyalty numbers associated with them. We never look for a year to bump one of the things that we're looking for and didn't plan that in our path to the 21 billion that we've laid out a couple of years ago. So we really didn't build any incrementalist into it as last year in the fourth quarter. We are making a concerted effort in the back half after we roll out a new point-of-sale system to use the loyalty information if they've completed their profile to do a prescreen on them for our credit card and try to get people to move along the value path from not having a loyalty card to having a [indiscernible] rewards card and then hopefully, getting them to sign up for our credit card. So we'll have more to talk to you about that, probably at the end of the fourth quarter. The new point-of-sale system isn't rolling out until late in the third quarter so won't have a lot of data on that until after holiday.

So I don't have any numbers from them yet. But I would suspect that would be consistent and beauty continues to be one of the better performing areas of the company.
