headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Kohl's Q2 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Certain statements made on this call, including projected financial results, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Secu
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Kohl's Q2 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Certain statements made on this call, including projected financial results, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Kohl's intends forward-looking terminology, such as believes, expects, may, will, should, anticipates, plans or similar expressions to identify forward-looking statements.
Such statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties which could cause Kohl's actual results to differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements.
Such risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to, those that are described in Item 1A in Kohl's most recent annual report on Form 10-K and as may be supplemented from time to time in Kohl's other filings with the SEC, all of which are expressly incorporated herein by reference.
Also, please note that replays of this recording will not be updated. So if you're listening after August 11, 2016, it is possible that the information discussed is no longer current. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. 
Now I turn -- I would like to turn the conference over to your host, Mr. Wes McDonald, Chief Financial Officer of Kohl's Department Stores. Please go ahead.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. With me today is Kevin Mansell, our Chairman, CEO and President. I'll start today's call by walking through our operational results and then Kevin will provide more details on our Greatness Agenda initiatives and then we'll take s
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. With me today is Kevin Mansell, our Chairman, CEO and President. I'll start today's call by walking through our operational results and then Kevin will provide more details on our Greatness Agenda initiatives and then we'll take some of your questions.
Comp sales decreased 1.8% for the quarter, below our expectations but significantly improved over first quarter results. Transactions per store were down 4.8% for the quarter. Average transaction value increased 300 basis points comprised of a 310 basis point increase in units per transaction and 10 basis point decrease in average unit retail. 
From a line of business perspective, men's was the strongest category while home was the weakest. All other businesses were generally consistent with the company average. On a regional basis, the Southeast, Midwest and West were strongest. The Northeast, South Central and Mid-Atlantic were below the company. Kevin will provide additional details on sales in his prepared remarks. 
Gross margin increased 53 basis points for the quarter, a significant improvement over the 140 basis point decrease we saw in the first quarter. The increase was driven by savings in both promotional markdown and permanent clearance markdowns. 
Our SG&A decreased $19 million to $986 million for the quarter and deleveraged only 3 basis points on a 2% decline in sales. Our teams continue to aggressively and effectively manage to our payroll as sales trends change versus our plan, but we were unable to leverage other expenses versus last year. 
IT and corporate expenses also deleveraged. Partially offset these increases were slightly higher credit income and lower variable store cost and marketing expenses. Depreciation expense was essentially flat to last year at $234 million. 
Our interest expense decreased $6 million to $78 million for the quarter as we saw the benefits of last summers refinancing. Our income tax rate was 37.5%. The tax rate decreased approximately 40 basis points from last year as a result of federal tax credits that were enacted in the fourth quarter of 2015. 
Net income on a reported GAAP basis for the quarter was $140 million and diluted earnings per share were $0.77. During the quarter, we recorded $128 million of expenses related to the store closures and corporate restructuring that we announced in February, bringing the year-to-date total to $192 million. As you saw on our release, the second quarter charge includes $119 million in future store lease obligations, $23 million in software licenses, which did not aligned with the strategic vision of our restructured IT leadership team and $7 million in severance and other costs, which were partially offset by the write-off of $21 million and net lease obligations that were previously recorded on our books. 
Of the year-to-date charge, $57 million is noncash write-offs of assets and liabilities that were previously recorded on our books. All of the severance will be paid out within 2 years. $119 million lease obligation charge represents a discounted value of rents and other lease liabilities under noncancelable lease terms. 
Our real estate team was able to terminate leases at 3 of the locations during the quarter. They're actively working with landlords and potential subtenants at the 13 remaining lease locations. Assuming worst-case scenario that we are unable to terminate any additional leases before their maturity, the $119 million will be paid out over the next 13 years. The maximum expected payment in every given -- any given year is less than $10 million. Actual cost reported for the quarter were $18 million higher than the high-end of our prior estimate. All of the [ph] is due to the write-off of software licenses. We do not expect material changes -- charges in future periods. 
Excluding the store closure and restructuring charges, net income increased 5% to $221 million and diluted earnings per share increased 14% to $1.22 per share. We currently operate 1,150 Kohl's stores with gross square footage of 99.1 million square feet and selling square footage of 82.7 million square feet. 
We also operate 12 FILA Outlets, which opened during the current quarter. We ended the quarter with $700 million in cash and cash equivalents, a decrease of $234 million from last year due to the timing of last summer's debt refinancing. As you may recall, we have $317 [ph] million from the refinancing proceeds on balance sheet in July of last year that we used to pay off bond tendered in August. 
Year-to-date, we generated almost $450 million in free cash flow, a $525 million improvement over the first half of last year. I'm very pleased with our inventory initiatives and our ability to decrease inventory dollars per store by 6% from the second quarter of last year despite the challenging sales environment. 
Units per store were 7% lower than the second quarter of last year. Our Accounts Payable as a percent of inventory decreased 182 basis points to 35%. All the decrease is due to lower receipts, especially in late June and in July, which have a larger impact on the AP to inventory ratio than receipts from earlier in the quarter. As you may recall, in the second quarter of last year, we had extraordinary amount of early arriving receipts due to improvement times and transit times. After the West Coast port [ph], operations return to normal. 
Capital expenditures were $340 million for the spring season, $37 million lower than last year, which included higher beauty spending as we finish the rollout of our enhanced beauty environment now in all stores and some corporate campus spending as we consolidate space here in Wisconsin. 
Weighted average diluted shares were $181 million for the quarter. During the quarter, we repurchased 3.7 million shares of our stock. We ended quarter with 181 million shares of stock outstanding. 
On Tuesday, our board declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.50 per share. The dividend is payable on September 21 to shareholders of record on September 7. 
After reviewing our results for the spring season, we are updating our guidance to $3.12 to $3.32 per diluted share. Excluding the store closure and restructuring charges, the guidance would be $3.80 to $4 per diluted share. 
The guidance includes the following assumptions for the fall season: Total sales decrease of 2.6%, up 0.6 to last year; a comp sales decrease of 2% to flat to last year; gross margin rate improvement of approximately 20 to 40 basis points over last year; and SG&A dollar growth of 0.5% to 2% over last year. 
I'll now turn it over to Kevin, who will provide some additional insights on our results.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Wes. The second quarter was below our expectations in the sales line. May was the weakest month of the quarter. June was aided by warm weather early in the month, along with favorable calendar shifts with Memorial Day falling in fiscal June and Fo
componenttext:
Thanks, Wes. The second quarter was below our expectations in the sales line. May was the weakest month of the quarter. June was aided by warm weather early in the month, along with favorable calendar shifts with Memorial Day falling in fiscal June and Fourth of July moving to fiscal July. 
July finished very strong as we moved our credit event a week closer to Back-to-School and those businesses, especially juniors, young men's and girls performed extremely well. 
Our seasonal business in the quarter followed a similar trajectory as the total company sales. A little more color on our sales. Men's was better than the company, with strength in active, young men's, basic and dress clothing and short and swimmer. Footwear ran with the company with strength in kids and men's dress casual and weakness in women's. 
Children's showed relatively strength in girls and boys while infants and toddlers was more difficult as we continue to work on revitalizing our Jumping Beans brand. Women's showed strength in active, intimate and swim, while updated contemporary and classic sportswear continued to remain more difficult. 
Accessories continued to be driven by beauty and fine jewelry with the remainder of the business being challenged. And finally, home trailed the company, but showed significant improvement from the first quarter as both bedding and luggage were strengths. 
We did a very good job of managing our inventory, gross margin and expenses during the quarter. Our gross margin rate increase of 53 basis points was better than our plan due to both better initial markup and lower promotional markdowns. Our inventory per store is now down 6%, in line with our expectations. 
We continue to expect to make progress on this thought the year, targeting end of third quarter levels of down mid-single-digits on a per-store basis. Our receipts will be down in the third quarter and slightly up in the fourth quarter as we bring in more transitional receipts than we did last year with the holiday season. 
We are being very conservative in our cold weather categories as we expect the third quarter to be soft with the fourth quarter improving versus last year's mild winter. 
On the SG&A line, almost every area of the company was able to pull back on their planned expenses to allow us to spend less than last year in dollars and significantly less than our plans. I continue to be impressed but the team's agility to pull back on expenses in a difficult sales environment. 
I'd now like to take a few minutes to update you on some of the initiatives within the Greatness Agenda. In our focus on product, on national national brands, our first quarter launches of Stride Rite and children's shoes and relaunched New Balance in the active area continue to pay dividends. 
The launch of Stride Rite helped kid shoes to outperform and New Balance achieved a 9% comp for the quarter. Our national brands in total were up low single digits, with active and wellness leading the way for the mid-single-digit comp. Nike continues to be very strong, achieving a low double-digit comp in the quarter. The active and wellness category itself is now 18% of our total business. Finally, national brand penetration increased approximately 200 basis points in the quarter. 
We're incredibly excited to add Under Armour to our active and wellness category in early 2017. We've already established the strong leadership position in the active and wellness area, and adding one of the most sought-after brands to our portfolio of offerings will allow us to project that leadership even more fully. As you know, this area has consistently been one of our fastest-growing categories in the store, and we would expect that adding Under Armour will extend that period of growth, accelerate the rate of growth and attract a new customer to our store at the same time. 
We relaunched SONOMA in the first quarter and have been happy with the results in both men's and women's as they've seen improvements versus their trend. One big initiative that we need to take a gross more of our private and exclusive brands is the need to improve our speed to market. 
We started to do this with our so brand in Juniors, and we're achieving double-digit comps this spring on less inventory than last year. Michelle is working with our product development teams to reduce the end-to-end cycle on our private and exclusive brands by 25% on average, and we have a goal of approximately 40% reduction in women's. 
This takes the success we have seen and saw with this initiative, and we're rolling out this to Candace and Juniors as well as urban pipeline in young men's. [ph] apparel will be the next area of focus. 
Our localization efforts are proving out in 2016 will be the year that all of our planning efforts for unique assortments by store will come to life in 90% of our assortments across all stores. 
As we exit the second quarter, approximately 70% of the assortment is already localized. We saw a modest lift in the spring season, achieving higher sales and lower inventory per store versus our control groups. We would expect the effect to improve as we gain more experience and enter key transitional periods by quarter 2 into quarter 3, where localized assortments should have a much bigger impact. 
And our focus around omnichannel initiatives, we continue to see strong results in digital demand, with online generated demand achieving a midteens increase, as we expected. We continue to invest in technology and training our stores to allow us to Ship from Store and provide Buy Online, Pick Up In Store capabilities, providing faster shipping times and more convenience for the time strapped customer. 
In the second quarter, the combination of Ship from Store and Buy Online, Pick Up In Store sales reached 21% of total dollar online demand and 23% of total unit online demand, both increasing versus the first quarter. 
We do believe we have a big opportunity there, both short and long-term, which we think will only continue to amplify the role and relevancy of our brick-and-mortar stores. 
And finally, our Kohl's app was downloaded by more than 13.5 million customers, continues to grow in both downloads but more importantly, usage, particularly aspects like the digital wallet. 
On a store update basis, we opened 12 Fila stores in May and 2 additional Off/Aisle stores in March, in both cases, we're generally pleased with the results and implementing operational changes as we learned from the results. 
We'll be opening 6 smaller format stores in the third quarter, adding to the 235,000-foot smaller stores we opened in the first quarter. Even more importantly than in our standard prototype stores, we've seen the importance of flexibility and localization in our offerings as each trade area is unique due to both small trade area and small store size. 
In 2017, we'll be looking for a small number of these stores to open in more populated markets to ascertain the potential and the possible use as a tool to serve trade areas where our full-size stores have too much square footage. 
In conclusion, I'm very happy with the efforts the organization has made around rightsizing our inventory and the resulting improvement in merchandise margin and cash flow. We reached our objective, aggressive objective of reducing inventories from last year by 6% per store at the end of the second quarter. And that will position us well to continue through  fall and holiday. I'm also equally pleased with the team's ability to manage expenses down in a tougher sales environment. 
We continue to work to create more momentum in our sales trend and this is our primary focus as we enter the fall and holiday. For the second quarter performance and sales certainly improved over the first quarter. We did have declines in foot traffic in our stores generally and this needs to be reversed to the positive. The key areas of focus and continuing that improvement in sales are, of course, marketing and merchandising. 
On the marketing side, we're is centered on projecting all of our loyalty components, rewards, Kohl's Cash and credit offers more completely. In our merchandising side, our focus is on improving our speed and agility across all of our businesses, but most importantly, our largest one, women's apparel. 
As you heard in our assumptions for the remainder of the year, we're looking to continue to improve on each of our key metrics the state conservative and the level of improvement expected. 
Thank you. And with that, we'll be happy to take your questions.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016

componenttext: When we think about 2Q and the sequential comp improvement that you saw from 3 months ago, I guess may first is where did you see the largest performance gap in terms of improvement? And then just looking ahead, you have a lot of upcoming initiatives, some new brands. What's the best way to think about the sustainable comp beyond all the noise that we're seeing this year?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think all the areas improved obviously over the first quarter, I think, the areas that are probably improved the most were men's, which lead the company with a positive comp. And Home although negative was a very difficult in the first quarter. We
componenttext: Sure. I think all the areas improved obviously over the first quarter, I think, the areas that are probably improved the most were men's, which lead the company with a positive comp. And Home although negative was a very difficult in the first quarter. We made some marketing changes, adding some [ph] distribution in both June and July, which we think disproportionately help some and we think that's going to be pointed in the right direction for the back half, which is a very important business in the fourth quarter.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kevin, Matt. On the more sustainability aspect of the comp looking forward, I think, as we sort of alluded to in the call, we're obviously very focused on the 2 most important elements, merchandising and marketing. On the merchandising side, I wou
componenttext: This is Kevin, Matt. On the more sustainability aspect of the comp looking forward, I think, as we sort of alluded to in the call, we're obviously very focused on the 2 most important elements, merchandising and marketing. On the merchandising side, I would say we're going to continue to drive our national brand strategy, in particular continue to amplify the importance of active and wellness because we think that the trend is taking hold very strongly. And while we have a good leadership position, I think, expanding the portfolio with Under Armour is going to make a massive difference. We're actually going to invest in the stores across the whole active area to make that areas stand out more as part of the launch of Under Armour. And then secondly, in merchandising, we touched on the fact that we know that we have to be faster in our product cycle from beginning to end on our private and exclusive brands. And so we've seen in the success in the areas where we piloted, and I think Michelle and the team is focused on expanding that to women's across the board and then, of course, to the overall store as well. On the marketing side, I think, we touched on probably the most important thing, which is continuing to wrap up all of our loyalty efforts more successfully, so pulling together the credit offers, Kohl's Cash and Yes2You Rewards. And I think as we analyze the results of our business over time, we probably have had opportunity there. They often stood alone and we're well connected in the communication with the customer. So I think Michelle feels pretty strongly that that's going to be a major opportunity going forward. So merchandise and marketing are our vocals, brands of the national side continue to have them but drive the ones we have and most importantly, improve the speed around our private and exclusive brands and then really focus on loyalty as a concept in our marketing.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just as a follow-up on the store base, can you talk about -- could you just help talk about the evaluation of the fleet under way, how are you weighing the potential closings longer term versus some of the cash flow you are getting in some
componenttext: Great. And then just as a follow-up on the store base, can you talk about -- could you just help talk about the evaluation of the fleet under way, how are you weighing the potential closings longer term versus some of the cash flow you are getting in some of these locations today? I guess any closings next year and then just thoughts longer term.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Kevin again, I can give you a part of the thinking and Wes can give you more specific financial aspect. I mean, overall, as you know we've closed some stores this year, and I think our expectation is we're going to be able to probably understand more
componenttext: It's Kevin again, I can give you a part of the thinking and Wes can give you more specific financial aspect. I mean, overall, as you know we've closed some stores this year, and I think our expectation is we're going to be able to probably understand more about the impact of that on markets and other trade areas inside of markets that might positively benefit from those store closures. I don't expect this to be able to do a thorough analysis to get a good understanding of that until next spring because we really need to go through the fall and holiday season to analyze that to a great degree. As a result, we honestly don't expect any store closures next year as of right now. The second part of that answer long-term is we think that our stores are really important and as we noted in the call, more and more were seen the role in relevancy of the store come to life through being able to use our stores as shipping points for customers as they go online to buy product but also pick up points as customers choose the convenience of buying online but begin up in the store and therefore shipping or time delay as well. And so that number continues to grow, I think, Wes was pretty excited about the fact that it reached 21% in dollars, 23% in units. I expect that at the end of the third quarter, it's going to be even higher and I would really expect at the end of the fourth quarter is going to be much of the higher just because of the nature of the business. As it relates to specific financials around stores, Wes could give you a good handle on that.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean I think we've mentioned in the past, we look at incremental, on an incremental cash flow basis. As we look at our lease expirations for next year, we don't have any stores that are underperforming that are going to expire next year on a lease.
componenttext: Yes, I mean I think we've mentioned in the past, we look at incremental, on an incremental cash flow basis. As we look at our lease expirations for next year, we don't have any stores that are underperforming that are going to expire next year on a lease. So that -- we would be close any lease stores next year for sure. There are some [ph] stores that are underperforming. We'll keep monitoring that. But to Kevin's point, until we get through holiday and understand how good we are at forecasting retain sales, it would be difficult for us to go ahead and say we're going to close more stores until we know how accurate we are on that.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I wanted to dig into loyalty a little bit. First, can you just update us on your efforts on converting the members to credit customers? And then bigger picture, now that we're close to 2 years into the program, just talk about some of your learn
componenttext: Okay. And I wanted to dig into loyalty a little bit. First, can you just update us on your efforts on converting the members to credit customers? And then bigger picture, now that we're close to 2 years into the program, just talk about some of your learnings, how effective the program has been and drive incremental visits are increasing transactions sizes, how the engagement of all members has evolved over time and any changes planned for the program moving forward?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, from a loyalty perspective, we've got a very nice lift last year. Our learnings from the second year is that we have to continue to create new ways for folks to get excited about loyalty. We started to do some events, we just did 1 in last week o
componenttext: I think, from a loyalty perspective, we've got a very nice lift last year. Our learnings from the second year is that we have to continue to create new ways for folks to get excited about loyalty. We started to do some events, we just did 1 in last week of July where we combined our friend and family event with a triple appoints for loyalty customers and that is some of the things that Kevin was talking about earlier about marketing. It's important to market the event but the 3 biggest things we have driving our results from a marketing perspective are credit card penetration, Kohl's Cash and our loyalty program. And we can't get those polls in front of the customers and get them to understand what the value of that is. As far as getting them to translate into credit card customers, I think, we've seen some success there. But honestly, we have a big data opportunity to merit the sources of data that we have within the company. There are people that register for our website on Kohls.com that provide us that information. There are people that register on the layout the profile. We need to marry that information together along with trying to get some income information so we can be able to prescreen those at the front register. We're going to be able to start to do that and more volume after we roll out our new point-of-sale program in the third quarter. But I don't expect to see significant enrollments in that until the spring of next year.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, 1 thing that has proven out, Mark, I think, Wes would tell you for sure, the Yes2You customer who is also a credit card customer is by far the most engaged consistent shopper in terms of these it's in dollars spent out Kohl's than any other custom
componenttext: I mean, 1 thing that has proven out, Mark, I think, Wes would tell you for sure, the Yes2You customer who is also a credit card customer is by far the most engaged consistent shopper in terms of these it's in dollars spent out Kohl's than any other customer we have. And they're also the most profitable customer for us. So I think from that perspective, we clearly are on a right path and as Wes kind of alluded to, what we need to do is accelerate the engagement of Yes2You customers who aren't credit card customers to consider moving that way.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the back half gross margin guidance. So plus 20 to 40, are you still planning for your inventory to be down as much as receipts were down coming into the third quarter? And if so, further opportunities to reduce clearance and init
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the back half gross margin guidance. So plus 20 to 40, are you still planning for your inventory to be down as much as receipts were down coming into the third quarter? And if so, further opportunities to reduce clearance and initial promotions?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our inventory is down mid-single digits, so kind of where we ended the second quarter. We always have a level of conservatism. Fourth quarter is always very competitive. I think you guys know that the e-commerce business spikes significantly in the fourth
componenttext: Our inventory is down mid-single digits, so kind of where we ended the second quarter. We always have a level of conservatism. Fourth quarter is always very competitive. I think you guys know that the e-commerce business spikes significantly in the fourth quarter. That is a bigger headwind the gross margin from a shipping cost perspective. So we're still going to see more improvement in the fourth quarter last year given our performance. We expect to see some improvement in the third quarter but, I think, it's just the level of conservatism, not knowing what's ahead of us. But from an inventory management perspective, we're going to hit those numbers. The team is really focused on being those inventory levels down, and I think you have seen prior results in the second quarter what benefits it has.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think you talked about bringing in more transitional product after holiday. Can you give us a little more context on what that might look like coming into the first quarter?
componenttext: And I think you talked about bringing in more transitional product after holiday. Can you give us a little more context on what that might look like coming into the first quarter?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really -- it's baked in the -- first of all, it's baked into the inventory assumptions Wes gave you, which is to continue to keep inventories down mid-single digit. I think Wes and I and Michelle would say, if we could do better than that, we'd be ha
componenttext: It's really -- it's baked in the -- first of all, it's baked into the inventory assumptions Wes gave you, which is to continue to keep inventories down mid-single digit. I think Wes and I and Michelle would say, if we could do better than that, we'd be happy. But that's currently certainly our focus right now. But there's a pretty big shift because we were due to high inventories last year, as you know, we were unable to deliver in the mid-November to mid-December periods fresh receipts that will allow us to transition out of holiday into spring. And that's going to be a pretty big change. So I think our viewpoint is, if you think about how we would then be positioned, both for holiday selling to more importantly in the spring, we're just going to be in a much better place because the percentage of our total units on hand that will be transitional will be much, much higher than it was last year.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick 2-part question. On the localization efforts, you guys have been piloting that at least with a group of stores a little bit lower than the rollout for the company. Just wondering if there's any data points around kind a longer tail insights y
componenttext: Just a quick 2-part question. On the localization efforts, you guys have been piloting that at least with a group of stores a little bit lower than the rollout for the company. Just wondering if there's any data points around kind a longer tail insights you've had from that pilot store group that you can share about gaining confidence the second half gross margin. And then secondly, Kevin may be for you on the active wellness, really great to see Under Armour coming to the store. The overall category sounds like it's up mid-singles. Nike is up low doubles. Just wondering how to reconcile those 2 just a little bit. Are you transitioning out some brands as you prepare for space or are there other underperforming rents under active and wellness?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: The localization, we sort of piloted versus control group. I mean, we're getting about 70 basis points less in comp in the areas that are localized versus the ones that aren't, with about 40 basis points reduction in inventory. So that's a pretty good res
componenttext: The localization, we sort of piloted versus control group. I mean, we're getting about 70 basis points less in comp in the areas that are localized versus the ones that aren't, with about 40 basis points reduction in inventory. So that's a pretty good result from our perspective. I think as we learn more as we continue to get better at this, it really is a combination of art and science. So the absolute inventory levels are easier to control. Trying to figure out what the differences in assortment is a little harder. I suspect we'll get better as we go throughout the year on that. And Kevin take the other question on the...

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the active and wellness area, I think, the way we're looking at that, nearly, is that the business is obviously growing faster than the overall apparel business. Certainly if you look at it industry-wide, the rate of growth is slowing just be
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the active and wellness area, I think, the way we're looking at that, nearly, is that the business is obviously growing faster than the overall apparel business. Certainly if you look at it industry-wide, the rate of growth is slowing just because the denominator is getting bigger in the business bigger and bigger and it's certainly a lot bigger for us in but if it continues to grow a lot faster than the rest of the store. And so active and wellness is going to be getting more space, it's got more inventory dedicated to it in our stores, and we're going to be going through this holiday a pretty major transformation of the presentation and space allocation and fixtures in our active and wellness areas in the stores to prepare for the Under Armour arrival. That will include updating and amplifying the rest of active and wellness in addition. There aren't any major brands that are going away at all. We just are seeing the continued move of consumers who are moving in the space, I think it's a long-term sort of life change for American consumers and we're just reflecting it in our inventory and space.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from that line of Paul Trachsel from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question will come from that line of Paul Trachsel from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. I wanted to ask a question on the top line. I believe you mentioned that July ended well and there's momentum heading here into the third quarter. You also spoke positively about the children's and juniors business. And I also know, Wes, I t
componenttext: Good morning. I wanted to ask a question on the top line. I believe you mentioned that July ended well and there's momentum heading here into the third quarter. You also spoke positively about the children's and juniors business. And I also know, Wes, I think, Thanksgiving is a little bit earlier this year, which could be helpful to 4Q. I guess I'm just surprised you didn't guide to the possibility of positive comps. If you could just maybe rectify that for us?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, what we've been in terms of the forward look is consistent with the way we always look at the guidance, Paul, which is to -- at the end of the first quarter, we really didn't update our guidance and the reason we didn't is we just felt like we di
componenttext: I think, what we've been in terms of the forward look is consistent with the way we always look at the guidance, Paul, which is to -- at the end of the first quarter, we really didn't update our guidance and the reason we didn't is we just felt like we didn't have a firm data point to be able to give you a true insight into the look for the year. Second quarter is now over. We see the improvement in the business. We see some of the inventory. Strategy is taking hold, the result improvement in margin, some of the SG&A initiatives that Wes and his team have implemented are taking hold as well. So we're just in a better position to use the current trend year-to-date to apply to the fall and holiday. Yes, it goes without saying Wes mentioned some of them, there's opportunity. We could do better on inventory. We could definitely do if you use second quarter as a data point, we could do better on margin. But, I think, it makes sense for us to just say, hey, year-to-date, here's where we're at, and we're looking for continued improvement on each of the lines but we don't want to get ahead of ourselves either.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. That's helpful. And then just to also better understand the comp composition. Could you just tell us what drove the UPTs up, I believe, 3 points. Just if there's any opportunity for a you are to increase in the back half for Shell we continue
componenttext: Fair enough. That's helpful. And then just to also better understand the comp composition. Could you just tell us what drove the UPTs up, I believe, 3 points. Just if there's any opportunity for a you are to increase in the back half for Shell we continue to believe that is flattish?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I Think AUR will increase in the back half due to increased penetration of national brands, and we ended the quarter with was Clarence than last year but we were aggressive out pricing that to the second quarter to get rid of it. So I think that was part
componenttext: I Think AUR will increase in the back half due to increased penetration of national brands, and we ended the quarter with was Clarence than last year but we were aggressive out pricing that to the second quarter to get rid of it. So I think that was part of the AUR drop, which hopefully will not be an issue in the back half as clearance continues to be lower than last year as we -- certainly in the fourth quarter as we move throughout the fall season. But, I think, the units are up because of the product is more scalable. People like what we're -- there's us more positive parts of the business held and there were in the first quarter. So some of those Back-to-School businesses that we mentioned, like young men's and juniors were positive for the entire quarter not just for July. So that gives us some hope going into the Back-to-School.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Dan Binder from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Dan Binder from Jefferies.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Dan Binder. Obviously, a tough industry backdrop. I was wondering if you could share a little bit of market share color if you have any and what you are missing on industry promotion. And then just lastly, kind of following on to the last question, t
componenttext: It's Dan Binder. Obviously, a tough industry backdrop. I was wondering if you could share a little bit of market share color if you have any and what you are missing on industry promotion. And then just lastly, kind of following on to the last question, the issue seems to be traffic. Obviously, as the product saleable and UPT is that, what more do you think you can do to drive traffic?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't really have the MPD data for the second quarter yet but I mean, I'm assuming that it will tell us that Amazon continues to gain market share as do off-price. We did a lot better in the second quarter than we did in the first, so I think that will
componenttext: We don't really have the MPD data for the second quarter yet but I mean, I'm assuming that it will tell us that Amazon continues to gain market share as do off-price. We did a lot better in the second quarter than we did in the first, so I think that will probably help us out as well. From be traffic, Kevin talked about that the how to do -- we are doing a good job with the credit card customer. They continue to shop us and shop us more than they did last year. We have to continue to make inroads with the noncredit card customer. That's part of the things that we talked about, I think, Mark asked the question earlier on loyalty, trying to engage in a more, trying to round them up to a higher level of reward to get them to come in more frequently and raise the response rate, to hammer home the differentiation of us providing Kohl's Cash and the ST rewards versus our competition. All of that takes time. It's not going to turn on a dime. So we just have to continue to do that. The if you start to notice our broadcast, I think, you'll see a more consistent theme on highlighting those vehicles versus just saying what the current event is, and I think over time, that's going to resonate with the customer and get them to come in to us more often.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think, Wes definitely covered the key point and if you think about what we covered in the call, Dan, we're definitely trying to bring up the message that we know that we've got it improved our speed, our speed strategy in private brands. An
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think, Wes definitely covered the key point and if you think about what we covered in the call, Dan, we're definitely trying to bring up the message that we know that we've got it improved our speed, our speed strategy in private brands. And we've been working on that, and we're now starting to get confidence that we can scale that across the store. So that's a big one, and I think Michelle is no more confident than ever that wrapping loyalty platforms together allows us to move customers up through Yes2You and credit card combos that would lead to higher engagement, higher sales. The other part that I think is probably important for you to understand is that we do think that we do have a big opportunity to amplify both the rollout but more importantly, the relevancy of our store base. So we made some store closures, as Wes said, we monitor stores all the time but there are no stores that we would anticipate closing next year right now. And the indicators through things like our ability to Ship from Store more effectively and less expensively and Buy Online, Pick Up In Store adoption rates kind of give us a sense that that's also a key element for us to see the value and having a broadened network of brick-and-mortar stores. I think it's a big advantage.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good segue, can you give us a sort of a rough idea what the gross margin headwind for its point of penetration in e-commerce with the learnings on Ship from Store taken into consideration split shipments and things you're doing around that. Has tha
componenttext: That's good segue, can you give us a sort of a rough idea what the gross margin headwind for its point of penetration in e-commerce with the learnings on Ship from Store taken into consideration split shipments and things you're doing around that. Has that impacted gross margin change versus what it was looking like a year ago as we get an increase in e-commerce penetration?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I still think it's going to be 30 basis points in total for the year. Shipping cost is about 20 and the mix is about 10. The BOPUS portion of that is obviously the biggest advantage in terms of profitability. That's moving up nicely but not to the poi
componenttext: No, I still think it's going to be 30 basis points in total for the year. Shipping cost is about 20 and the mix is about 10. The BOPUS portion of that is obviously the biggest advantage in terms of profitability. That's moving up nicely but not to the point where it can help us out significantly again, I think, the fourth quarter will be a big indicator of how good that can be. You alluded to split shipments, that's something we're working on a very diligently. The Ship from Store option for us makes us competitive with Amazon prime and in terms of we can get the shipment to the persons house in less than 2 days about 90-some percent of the time. So speed is a big initiative from that perspective. But if we had to ship in 2 packages, that's a problem. So we're continuing to fine-tune our algorithms to allow more packages to go together and not split the shipments. And I suspect we'll have more improvement as we move into the back half on that.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, is it fair to say, Wes, that the opportunity all in margin is more about improving the that merchandise margin the next few years?
componenttext: I mean, is it fair to say, Wes, that the opportunity all in margin is more about improving the that merchandise margin the next few years?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the shipping cost given where we think online is going to go is going to probably be around that 30 basis points. But if we can increase the apparel penetration through the combination of having both better product and smartly extending the a
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the shipping cost given where we think online is going to go is going to probably be around that 30 basis points. But if we can increase the apparel penetration through the combination of having both better product and smartly extending the assortments and things like special sizes and begun tall, even footwear with some of the wide shoe options, that will allow us to do a lot better from a merchandise margin perspective. We made a lot of progress online from a clearance perspective and cleaning that up and I think there's also opportunity with reducing SKUs, which will help as well.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just the last item, anything more on brands for this year in terms of brand announcements or opportunities? I mean, any particular categories or anything you're ready to talk about?
componenttext: And just the last item, anything more on brands for this year in terms of brand announcements or opportunities? I mean, any particular categories or anything you're ready to talk about?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, nothing to share with you right now. As we said, that continues to be a key focus for Michelle, both adding new brands to our portfolio but also strengthening the ones in key areas, Health and Wellness is a great example with Nike. And then secondly,
componenttext: No, nothing to share with you right now. As we said, that continues to be a key focus for Michelle, both adding new brands to our portfolio but also strengthening the ones in key areas, Health and Wellness is a great example with Nike. And then secondly, the speed initiative in private brands has an equally important role as she sees the mix of national and private brands evolving.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Paul Lejuez from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Paul Lejuez from Citi.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Macy's announced store closing program today. I'm just curious if know you've noticed any pickup in your stores that are close to the last class of Macy's stores to close. And I think that's really but just in the context of Macy's, did you make you think
componenttext: Macy's announced store closing program today. I'm just curious if know you've noticed any pickup in your stores that are close to the last class of Macy's stores to close. And I think that's really but just in the context of Macy's, did you make you think any differently about the right number of stores is longer term? I know you don't have anything lined up for close next year but what's the right open up size of the fleet?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wes might be able to answer the first part I can definitely reiterate.
componenttext: Wes might be able to answer the first part I can definitely reiterate.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, those are most very similar to win ending up strategy we didn't see a big pickup. We haven't seen a big pickup from the Macy's closures I would think the mall-based retailers would see more of that. And then from a store closure perspective, it's
componenttext: I mean, those are most very similar to win ending up strategy we didn't see a big pickup. We haven't seen a big pickup from the Macy's closures I would think the mall-based retailers would see more of that. And then from a store closure perspective, it's hard to get predict the future. If we can start to try off-line sales more consistently, that should make the stores better. I did see a we've mentioned earlier, we don't see any stores we're going to close next year when we get a better idea of what the retained sales are going to be from the 18 that we just closed in June, that will tell us what our projections are going forward and make us feel better about either with be more aggressive on closing stores closing stores or more conservative once we get that information.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and just generally though, Paul, again, I think, we all feel that the role of brick-and-mortar stores in our future, we're actually more convicted about it than less convicted about it. Now there can be individual stores as we go through the next few
componenttext: Yes, and just generally though, Paul, again, I think, we all feel that the role of brick-and-mortar stores in our future, we're actually more convicted about it than less convicted about it. Now there can be individual stores as we go through the next few years that Wes might determine financially don't make sense to have. But if you think about all the things we're talking about, whether it's the rollout of these 35,000 square foot stores as a potential to replace larger stores over time are it's all of the easy experience initiatives that we're implementing or it's the adoption of Buy Online, Pick Up In Store and utilization from of Ship from Store to convenience on online orders, easier. And as Wes just said, faster, they all, to a greater extent, kind of point us towards saying having a really strong base and portfolio of stores is an important element of why we're actually going to be successful in the future. Fewer stores generally are not going to be a ticket to success in our mind. That doesn't mean if stores don't pass a financial hurdle that we won't close to them or downsize them.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we will have smaller stores in the future. As leases comes up, I think it will be smarter for us to relocate into smaller store the next 5 years. But, I think, Kevin's right, distribution poitn as digital becomes a bigger part of everybody's business
componenttext: Yes, we will have smaller stores in the future. As leases comes up, I think it will be smarter for us to relocate into smaller store the next 5 years. But, I think, Kevin's right, distribution poitn as digital becomes a bigger part of everybody's business is important.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 1 separate 1. How can we think about the launch of Under Armour? How big can it be in your may be long-term as well how big can that business before you guys?
componenttext: Just 1 separate 1. How can we think about the launch of Under Armour? How big can it be in your may be long-term as well how big can that business before you guys?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we don't scale things like that in terms of volume or that. Externally and internally, we have a plan. I think, the way Michelle spoke about it when she announced the launch of it is it will be the biggest launch that we've done. And it's going
componenttext: Obviously, we don't scale things like that in terms of volume or that. Externally and internally, we have a plan. I think, the way Michelle spoke about it when she announced the launch of it is it will be the biggest launch that we've done. And it's going to be funded accordingly. And more importantly, from my standpoint, Michelle is looking at the overall active area because as you just heard in the script, we have brands in that area that are performing at an extremely high level. So we are not looking for Under Armour to diminish the rate of growth another brands. We're looking to expand our opportunities in active and wellness and also expand for Under Armour appoints of a distribution to reach customers that they have not been at success in reaching. So we feel great about that.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Michael Binetti from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Michael Binetti from UBS.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could I just ask you really playing for modeling, what are you baking in your assumption of traffic for the second half inside resource guide? Can you give us a couple of pieces I just want to try
componenttext: Could I just ask you really playing for modeling, what are you baking in your assumption of traffic for the second half inside resource guide? Can you give us a couple of pieces I just want to try

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: You gave us credit for being smarter than we really are. So I'm just thinking we're going to be down somewhere between down 2, which is the run rate had just recently and flat. We think there are a lot of things going, moving in our direction to get to fl
componenttext: You gave us credit for being smarter than we really are. So I'm just thinking we're going to be down somewhere between down 2, which is the run rate had just recently and flat. We think there are a lot of things going, moving in our direction to get to flat. If we get to flat, it's going to be because traffic is less negative. I don't think traffic has to be positive for us to be flat because between a combination of Pfizer more units or slightly higher AUR or hopefully both, we're going to have a higher transaction value.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then I guess the -- 1 thing we talked about in the quarter and you mentioned a few times of these the speed initiative on private label. Can you just help us think about what the overall opportunity is there and I apologize if you mentioned is d
componenttext: Okay, and then I guess the -- 1 thing we talked about in the quarter and you mentioned a few times of these the speed initiative on private label. Can you just help us think about what the overall opportunity is there and I apologize if you mentioned is directly but maybe the margin consumption you are seeing. Regarding you said you could give us ex percent of private and exclusive label we'll get there over time. But maybe just sort of thing about how that impacts the margins. And then secondly, do that is obviously are focusing on private and exclusive. But some of the other chatter on the industry has been some of the national brands trying to integrate more deeply with the retailers to see if they can speed up in that wholesale retail the relationship, is there any opportunity to do that as you look beyond what you'll be able to do in the private label side?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- its Kevin. I think there is definitely opportunity in the national brand portfolio to improve speed and it's definitely a focus for many of our key suppliers. We're probably talking more about it with you on the private brand side because we co
componenttext: I think -- its Kevin. I think there is definitely opportunity in the national brand portfolio to improve speed and it's definitely a focus for many of our key suppliers. We're probably talking more about it with you on the private brand side because we completely control that, and we know the elements of the cycle from design all the way through delivery that we can take time out on, and we piloted and experimented and it's in the results. I mean, I think, frankly, Michelle would tell you that she believes the metric that will improve, if we effectively scale up speed beyond where it's been tested and piloted so far, will be sales. Yes, there's a corresponding positive that comes with more effective inventory and therefore, if sales improve, as you know, margins on private brands are quite a bit higher. And so there's a possible margin implication that would be to the positive as well. But I think that the number she is looking to change, the trend line on is implement speed on our more relevant product, which will sell better, turn a little faster and indirectly, I think, raise our merchandise margin because we'll just be doing better on private brands.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very comprehensive call. Just a question on the private brands and their evolution. Clearly, there's some winners and losers in that portfolio and wondering if there's an editing process that will occur over the next year or is over some of the private br
componenttext: Very comprehensive call. Just a question on the private brands and their evolution. Clearly, there's some winners and losers in that portfolio and wondering if there's an editing process that will occur over the next year or is over some of the private brands go away and are replaced by national brands or by expansion of the private label? So wondering how you're thinking about the private-label brand portfolio and any opportunity now to edit it down a bit, to focus it?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's, Kevin. There's definitely editing opportunities in our private brands and when I say private brands, I mean including our exclusive brand portfolio. So the entire portfolio that represents almost 50% of our business. And I think that the factors tha
componenttext: It's, Kevin. There's definitely editing opportunities in our private brands and when I say private brands, I mean including our exclusive brand portfolio. So the entire portfolio that represents almost 50% of our business. And I think that the factors that will impact of that will be how quickly we can scale up the speed initiative. We'll probably tell us pretty quickly which of the brands benefit the most from that and therefore, we'll point us in the right direction in terms of downsizing and then eliminating others. We definitely know that, that's an opportunity for us. We've broadened the base of private and exclusive brands we have to offer over the last 5 years quite substantially, and I think Mitchell feels like there's a chance to tighten it up. Our big private brands though, the billion dollar plus brands of SONOMA and Croft & Barrow and [ph] 9, they're not go away and they are the ones that probably benefit the most. There is always good things and bad things in private and exclusive brand results but generally, the really good things have been the brands like so that have had the speed initiative applied. And the things that have struggled more and also things like SONOMA where we've kind of relaunched it. And the things that have struggled more are those brands where we haven't had any adoption of the speed initiative. So that's kind of how we're thinking about it.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We were just wondering I guess, 2 questions. One, about the guidance cut. So it seems like Q1 you may have missed your internal plan by $0.10. It seems like you've more than made it up here in Q2. So with the business improving, we're wondering why you're
componenttext: We were just wondering I guess, 2 questions. One, about the guidance cut. So it seems like Q1 you may have missed your internal plan by $0.10. It seems like you've more than made it up here in Q2. So with the business improving, we're wondering why you're taking down the full year guidance? What metrics are you seeing or you being more cautious on? And then the second question is with the lower SG&A levels, are you finding that you have a new lowered leverage point going forward? Is your D&A now may be going to grow a little slower or come down? Can you maybe talk about go forward, what are some things that can continue?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're pretty new, Brian. So I'm going to help you with these. The reason we -- first of all, we didn't take the guidance down from her the consensus guy was, you best of that and for us all thank you for that. But the reason is that $3.8 to $4 [ph] we di
componenttext: You're pretty new, Brian. So I'm going to help you with these. The reason we -- first of all, we didn't take the guidance down from her the consensus guy was, you best of that and for us all thank you for that. But the reason is that $3.8 to $4 [ph] we did report that we'll make $3.80. Our internal expectations from a sales perspective are to improve. If we can hit those, we'll make $4. From a leverage perspective, we've lowered our internal goal from a 2% to 1.5%. We did much better than that this spring. I mean, if you do the math of the numbers I gave you, we should leverage a little bit above a flat comp for the year. I can't sign up for that forever. But we do have a lot of initiatives going forward were I hope we do better than the 1.5% but that's what we're committing to at this point.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016

componenttext: This was the last batch of rollout. The beauty, the beauty environment and the stores we just rolled out in the spring average about 34% comp in beauty, which was similar to the first 2 stages. So it is now complete. And it should continue to comp in those 267 stores in the 30% range through the balance of the year and slightly into next. So that's been a big success, and we're very happy with it. Michelle is working on trying to get additional brands to strengthen that environment now that the physical environment has rolled out.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had a question about weatherproofing and your ability to really navigate the environment when weather is more risky and when weather is an opportunity. How would you dissect what factors may lead to that happening over time, whether it be categories an
componenttext: We had a question about weatherproofing and your ability to really navigate the environment when weather is more risky and when weather is an opportunity. How would you dissect what factors may lead to that happening over time, whether it be categories and it looks like speed is a great opportunity as well. And then if you could help us test for our knowledge, dissect what's happening to your consumer as we kind of reconcile low unemployment and some wage growth against what's been tougher on traffic. And just our last question is on Amazon. With the competition evolving on Amazon, what are you focused on just to ensure you are on Amazon a bowl? Like what is in your customer overlap is in product over that?

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of questions, Oliver. On the how we think about we're navigating the weather changes that have been in regions and parts of the country over time. I think generally, there's 2 answers to that, Oliver. One is, and I think Wes may have mentioned it, i
componenttext: A lot of questions, Oliver. On the how we think about we're navigating the weather changes that have been in regions and parts of the country over time. I think generally, there's 2 answers to that, Oliver. One is, and I think Wes may have mentioned it, if not, I'll make sure that you know. As we look into the fall and holiday, we definitely are planning, we plan down to seasonal categories, substantially more than the overall business. So we feel like we want to make sure that we're in front of that and not chasing it, and we much rather be in a position where we run low or do have to chase product in highly seasonal category. So the plan has a aspect to it. The longer term answer is definitely is the speed initiative because many of our national brand businesses are less weather sensitive. And most of our private and exclusive brand product is actually relatively highly weather sensitive. So I think longer term, we feel like the speed initiative is the solution. We've positioned private and exclusive brands, I think, Wes, on an inventory basis really well in to the fall and holiday. We're down.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're down like midteens.
componenttext: Yes, we're down like midteens.

headline: Kohl's Corp., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: In total inventories, so I think we're really in a good place on that. In terms of consumer behavior, I think that there's isn't any new news there. We have modest improvement in our business and in traffic but it's still negative. So until such time as w
componenttext: In total inventories, so I think we're really in a good place on that. In terms of consumer behavior, I think that there's isn't any new news there. We have modest improvement in our business and in traffic but it's still negative. So until such time as we can implement these merchandising and marketing changes, we don't plan for traffic to turn positive. And so as I said earlier on the call, we're planning traffic to be lower than sales in the near term. And in terms of competition, I think, Wes also address that a little bit earlier, we continue to see, and we expect that both Amazon and generally off-price space is gaining share. And so to the extent we can, we are really focused on making changes to our business model that would just allow us to compete more effectively. And one of the things that we're probably doing and have a strong point of view about is the importance of our stores to do that. We still -- we're in a good position in that we have stores who pass our hurdles and are financially performing but traffic is down. So if we don't get that turnaround at some point, we have the building of new stores more effectively. But we're piloting these much smaller stores as perhaps replacements so we continue to have points of distribution. But they are less square footage and then we are trying to you device is a must point of what distribution to BOPUS in Ship from Store strategy. So I think Wes, and I, Michelle, [ph], [ph], we all feel like stores a really important part of our future, and we just have to make them work harder for us customers and having more presence in markets has an impact on brand awareness, in share awareness, beyond just distributing the product and access point. It just makes you a more important competitor in any particular market across the country and we just have to make them.
